{{Infobox football biography | name = Kenneth Zohore | image =Kenneth Zohore.jpg | image_size = | caption = Zohore playing for [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] in 2016 | fullname = Albin Kenneth Dahrup Zohore<ref name="FIFAU17-squadlist">{{cite web|title=FIFA U-17 World Cup Mexico 2011 List of Players|url=https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/tournament/competition/01/45/16/03/fu17_2011_squadlists.pdf|work=fifa.com|publisher=[[FIFA]]|accessdate=25 September 2012}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1994|1|31}} | birth_place = [[Copenhagen]], Denmark | height = 1.89 m<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/teams/first-team/forward/kenneth-zohore/ |title=Kenneth Zohore |publisher=Cardiff City F.C. |accessdate=22 December 2018}}</ref> | position = [[Forward (association football)|Striker]] | currentclub = [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] | clubnumber = 10 | youthyears1 = 2002–2006|youthclubs1 = [[BK Skjold]] | youthyears2 = 2006–2009|youthclubs2 = [[Kjøbenhavns Boldklub|KB]] | years1 = 2010–2012|clubs1 = [[F.C. Copenhagen|Copenhagen]] |caps1 = 16 |goals1 = 1 | years2 = 2012–2015 |clubs2 = [[ACF Fiorentina|Fiorentina]] |caps2 = 0 |goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2013–2014|clubs3 = → [[Brøndby IF]] (loan)|caps3 = 25|goals3 = 5 | years4 = 2014|clubs4 = → [[IFK Göteborg]] (loan)|caps4 = 5|goals4 = 2 | years5 = 2015–2016|clubs5 = [[Odense Boldklub|OB]]|caps5 = 24 |goals5 = 9 | years6 = 2016 |clubs6 = [[K.V. Kortrijk]]|caps6=0 |goals6 = 0 | years7 = 2016 |clubs7 = → [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] (loan)|caps7=12 |goals7 = 2 | years8 = 2016– |clubs8 = [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]]|caps8 = 78 |goals8 = 22 | nationalyears1 = 2009–2011|nationalteam1 = [[Denmark national under-17 football team|Denmark U17]] |nationalcaps1 = 24 |nationalgoals1 = 13 | nationalyears2 = 2012|nationalteam2 = [[Denmark national under-18 football team|Denmark U18]] |nationalcaps2 = 2 |nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2010–2013 |nationalteam3 = [[Denmark national under-19 football team|Denmark U19]] |nationalcaps3 = 16 |nationalgoals3 = 6 | nationalyears4 = 2013–2017 |nationalteam4 = [[Denmark national under-21 football team|Denmark U21]] |nationalcaps4 = 20 |nationalgoals4 = 8 | club-update = 17:06, 2 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 20:38, 21 August 2017 (UTC) }} '''Albin Kenneth Dahrup Zohore'''<ref name="FIFAU17-squadlist" /> (born 31 January 1994) is a [[Denmark|Danish]] professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[forward (association football)|striker]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]].
He began his career in his native Denmark, making his professional debut for [[F.C. Copenhagen|Copenhagen]] at the age of 16, becoming the youngest player to play in the [[Danish Superliga]]. Regarded as a promising youngster, he joined Italian side [[ACF Fiorentina|Fiorentina]] in 2012 but struggled to break into the first-team and, following loan spells with [[Brøndby IF]] and [[IFK Göteborg]], he returned to Denmark on a permanent basis by joining [[Odense Boldklub|OB]] in 2015.
==Personal life== Zohore was born in [[Copenhagen]] to a Danish mother and an Ivorian father.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bt.dk/superligaen/fcks-zohore-drogba-er-min-mentor |title=FCK's Zohore: Drogba er min mentor |publisher=bt.dk |language=Danish |date=20 July 2011 |accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.violanews.com/altre-news/lex-viola-zohore-tiene-a-galla-per-ora-litalia/ |title=L’ex viola Zohore regala la qualificazione all’Italia |publisher=Viola News |author=Federico Generelli |language=Italian |date=24 June 2017 |accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> His father is the second cousin of former Chelsea striker [[Didier Drogba]].<ref>{{cite web|title=FCK's Zohore: Drogba is my mentor|url=http://www.sporten.dk/superligaen/fcks-zohore-drogba-er-min-mentor|work=Sporten.dk|publisher=[[Sporten.dk]]|accessdate=25 June 2013}}</ref>
==Career==
===Copenhagen=== After spells with [[BK Skjold]] and [[Kjøbenhavns Boldklub|KB]], Zohore joined the youth system at [[F.C. Copenhagen|Copenhagen]], being promoted to the under-19 squad at the age of 15 in 2009. He joined the first-team's training camp in [[Marbella]], Spain, on 2 February 2010 together with Thobias Skovgaard.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://fck.dk/index.php?pageid=754&newsid=9963 |title=Afrejse tirsdag |accessdate=2010-02-03 |date=2010-02-01 |publisher=F.C. Copenhagen |language=Danish }}</ref> He made his professional debut for the club on 7 March 2010, at the age of 16 years and 35 days old,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.superstats.dk/spillere/alder-alltime |title=Yngst/aeldst |publisher=superstats.dk |language=Danish |accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref> becoming the youngest player to ever make his debut in the [[Danish Superliga]] after replacing [[César Santin]] in the 73rd minute during a 5–0 victory against [[Aarhus Gymnastikforening|AGF]].<ref name="skifter">{{cite web |url=http://fck.dk/nyhedsvisning/?newsid=12286 |title=Kenneth Zohore skifter til Fiorentina |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2012-01-31 |publisher=[[fck.dk]] |language=Danish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120612114933/http://fck.dk/nyhedsvisning/?newsid=12286 |archivedate=2012-06-12 |df= }}</ref><ref name="rfr">{{cite web |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/rise-fall-rise-again-kenneth-12628614 |title=The rise, fall and rise again of Kenneth Zohore: An insight into Cardiff City's prodigious talent who lost his way |publisher=WalesOnline |author=Dominic Booth |date=20 February 2017 |accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> However, the match was his only appearance for the first-team during the 2009–10 season.<ref name="Soccerway">{{cite web |url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/kenneth-dahrup-zohore/136137/ |title=K. Zohore |publisher=Soccerway |accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref>
On 20 October 2010, Zohore made his first [[UEFA Champions League]] appearance for Copenhagen, playing against [[FC Barcelona]] at [[Camp Nou]]. The 16-year-old striker replaced [[César Santin]] in the 74th minute of the game, becoming one of the youngest players ever to play in the Champion's League.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/11/23/10-youngest-champions-league-debutants-including-juventus-moise/kenneth-zohore/ |title=The 10 youngest Champions League debutants including Juventus' Moise Kean – how did their careers pan out? |publisher=The Daily Telegraph |date=23 November 2016 |accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> Ten days later, he scored his first senior goal for FC Copenhagen in the Danish Superliga against [[Lyngby Boldklub]]. He is the second youngest goalscorer ever in the Danish Superliga, after [[Mads Beierholm]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.superstats.dk/spillere/alder-alltime?vis=MaalYngst |title=Yngste Malscorere, All-Time |publisher=superstats.dk |language=Danish |accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref>
Zohore attracted attention from numerous clubs around Europe, spending time on trial at [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], also being approached by Chelsea player Didier Drogba after the two sides met in a Champions League fixture, and [[Inter Milan]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sporten.dk/fodbold/den-nye-bendtner |title=Den nye Bendtner (The new Bendtner) |accessdate=2010-03-07 |date=2010-02-05 |publisher=[[Sporten.dk]] |language=Danish }}</ref> His performances saw him described as "one of the top striking prospects anywhere in the world".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11668/6820678/zohore-reveals-drogba-chat |title=Zohore reveals Drogba 'chat' |publisher=Sky Sports |author=Richard Torgerson |date=18 March 2011 |accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref>
===Fiorentina & loan spells=== On 31 January 2012, FC Copenhagen announced that Zohore had signed for Italian side [[ACF Fiorentina]] on his 18th birthday for a fee in the region of £1 million.<ref name="skifter"/> He was given shirt no. 33.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.legaseriea.it/c/document_library/get_file?uuid=c539b06c-4a16-4487-8fe1-83f9efefdfb5&groupId=10192 |title=Comunicati Stampa N°123 (2011–12) |date=12 May 2012 |accessdate=1 July 2012 |publisher=Lega Serie A |language=Italian }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> However, Zohore never featured for the first team, later stating that he was "too young" to cope with the strong competition for places.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://sport.sky.it/calcio/europei/2017/06/25/zohore-dalla-fiorentina-spinge-l-italia-in-semifinale.html |title=Da meteora viola a eroe, l'Italia ringrazia Zohore |publisher=Sky Sports |language=Italian |date=25 June 2017 |accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref>
On 8 August 2013, [[Brøndby IF]], managed by Zohore's former coach at Danish youth levels [[Thomas Frank (football manager)|Thomas Frank]], announced that they had agreed a deal with [[ACF Fiorentina]] to sign Zohore on a season-long loan with the option to buy at the end of the year for between €2.2 and €2.3 million.<ref name="bt">{{cite web |url=http://www.bt.dk/superligaen/saadan-har-broendby-kokset-i-zohore-handel |title=Sådan har Brøndby kokset i Zohore-handel |publisher=bt.dk |language=Danish |date=28 July 2013 |accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://brondby.com/nyhed/2013/08/08/kenneth-zohore-til-broendby-if |title=Kenneth Zohore to Brøndby IF |publisher=Brøndby IF |language=Danish |date=8 August 2013 |accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref> Brøndby paid a loan fee of nearly €100,000 to secure the move, beating off competition from German side [[Hannover 96]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jv.dk/sport/Saa-meget-skal-Broendby-betale-for-Zohore/artikel/1593204 |title=Så meget skal Brøndby betale for Zohore |publisher=Jydske Vestkysten |author=Søren Sorgenfri |language=Danish |date=26 July 2016 |accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref> however the transfer nearly collapsed close to completion as Brøndby were unaware of their need to pay Zohore's wages during the loan spell but the loan was eventually completed.<ref name="bt"/> Brøndby were hopeful of completing the transfer on a permanent basis but were unable to meet Fiorentina's valuation.<ref name="juble">{{cite web |url=http://3point.dk/zohore-vil-ikke-juble-hvis-han-scorer-mod-brondby/ |title=Zohore vil ikke juble, hvis han scorer mod Brøndby |publisher=3point.dk |author=Nanna Møller Karlsen |language=Danish |date=11 March 2015 |accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref>
On 11 August 2014 [[IFK Göteborg]] announced that Zohore had joined the club on a loan deal from Fiorentina.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ifkgoteborg.se/Nyheter/2014/Augusti/Klart-med-Zohore/ | title=Klart med Zohore | publisher=IFK Göteborg | date=11 August 2014 | accessdate=11 August 2014 | language=Swedish | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140915032129/http://www.ifkgoteborg.se/Nyheter/2014/Augusti/Klart-med-Zohore/# | archive-date=2014-09-15 | dead-url=yes | df= }}</ref> He made his debut 13 August 2014 in an away game against Åtvidaberg BK coming on as a substitute. In his home game debut against Brommapojkarna, 17 August 2014, Zohore scored his first goal for IFK Göteborg when he only had been on the pitch three minutes after coming on as a substitute in the 83rd minute.
===Odense Boldklub=== On 3 February 2015, Zohore returned to the Danish Superliga with [[Odense Boldklub]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ob.dk/artikel/ob-skriver-kontrakt-med-kenneth-zohore.aspx |title=OB skriver kontrakt med Kenneth Zohore |accessdate=3 February 2015 |date=3 February 2015 |publisher=Odense Boldklub |language=Danish }}</ref> following the termination of his contract with Fiorentina.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ob.dk/artikel/ob-saelger-kenneth-zohore.aspx|title=OB sælger Kenneth Zohore|last=Wamsler|first=Morten|date=1 February 2016|website=|publisher=Odense Boldklub|language=Danish|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=21 August 2017}}</ref>
===Cardiff City=== ====2015–16==== On the final day of the winter transfer window in January 2016, Zohore joined Championship side [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on loan from Belgian side [[K.V. Kortrijk]], a club also owned by Cardiff chairman [[Vincent Tan]], who signed him that same day from OB for a fee reported to be around £1 million.<ref name="details">{{cite web |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/details-kenneth-zohores-cardiff-city-10821063 |title=The details of Kenneth Zohore's Cardiff City loan as it emerges deal could contain clause to make move permanent |publisher=WalesOnline |author=Chris Wathan |date=1 February 2016 |accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35435452 |title=Kenneth Zohore joins Cardiff City from Vincent Tan's Kortrijk |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 February 2016 |accessdate=1 February 2016}}</ref> At the time, Cardiff were under a transfer ban following a breach of financial fair play rules and were banned from signing players on permanent contracts,<ref name="details"/> although club sources stated that the deal was not made to circumvent the transfer ban and that he was moving to Cardiff to "boost his experience".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/cardiff-city-owner-vincent-tan-10811871 |title=Cardiff City owner Vincent Tan set to buy Kenneth Zohore for Belgian club and loan striker to Bluebirds |publisher=WalesOnline |author=Chris Wathan |date=31 January 2016 |accessdate=17 August 2017}}</ref> He made his debut on 6 February in a goalless draw against [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]], coming on as a substitute in place of [[Sammy Ameobi]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35447347 |title=Cardiff City 0–0 Milton Keynes Dons |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 February 2016 |accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> He featured frequently in the final months of the 2015–16 season as a substitute, scoring his first goal for the club on 19 April 2016 during a 2–1 defeat against [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35447347 |title=Brentford 2–1 Cardiff City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=19 April 2016 |accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> He was rewarded with his first start for the club in the following match, a 2–1 victory over [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]], during which he scored Cardiff's opening goal.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36060676 |title=Cardiff City 2–1 Bolton Wanderers |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 April 2016 |accessdate=18 August 2017}}</ref> He finished his loan spell having made 12 appearances, scoring twice.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/cardiff-city-sign-danish-striker-11574955 |title=Cardiff City sign Danish striker Kenneth Zohore while Idriss Saadi heads out on season-long loan deal |publisher=WalesOnline |author=Anthony Woolford |date=6 July 2016 |accessdate=20 August 2017}}</ref>
====2016–17==== Zohore went on to sign a three-year deal in the Welsh capital in June 2016 for an undisclosed fee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/cardiff-city-sign-danish-striker-11574955|title=Cardiff City sign Danish striker Kenneth Zohore while Idriss Saadi heads out on season-long loan deal|last=Woolford|first=Anthony|date=6 July 2016|website=|publisher=WalesOnline|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=6 July 2016}}</ref> However, new manager [[Paul Trollope]], who had replaced [[Russell Slade]] following the end of the previous season, favoured fellow new signings [[Frederic Gounongbe]] and [[Rickie Lambert]] following his appointment with Zohore making only one start in the opening four months of the season, during a 1–0 defeat to [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]] in the first round of the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] on 11 August 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36971967 |title=Bristol Rovers 1–0 Cardiff City (AET) |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 August 2016 |accessdate=20 August 2017}}</ref> With the club struggling, Trollope was replaced by [[Neil Warnock]] and, in December 2016, Zohore impressed as a half time substitute during a 2–1 victory against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]].<ref name="surprise">{{cite web |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/cardiff-city-manager-neil-warnock-12338343 |title=Cardiff City manager Neil Warnock could cancel January striker search if Kenneth Zohore continues surprise form |publisher=WalesOnline |author=Phil Smith |date=18 December 2016 |accessdate=20 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff City 2–1 Wolverhampton Wanderers |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38217655 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 December 2016 |accessdate=13 December 2016}}</ref> Following the match, Warnock praised Zohore's performances in his first two appearances under him, commenting that Zohore had been "a little lazy" during his time at Cardiff and that a transfer away from the club had been considered,<ref name="form">{{cite web |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/remarkable-stats-show-kenneth-zohore-12664557 |title=The remarkable stats that show Kenneth Zohore is in better form than Ronaldo, Higuain, Diego Costa and many more huge stars |publisher=WalesOnline |author=Dominic Booth |date=27 February 2017 |accessdate=20 August 2017}}</ref> but that his improvement meant that he could not "buy anybody better than him at the minute".<ref name="surprise"/> He went onto score his first goal on Boxing Day during a 2–2 draw with [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Brentford 2–2 Cardiff City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38360565 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 December 2016 |accessdate=26 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Neil Warnock: Kenneth Zohore will save Cardiff money in transfer market |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38498047 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 January 2017 |accessdate=3 January 2017}}</ref> Zohore was nominated for Championship Player of the Month in February, following a goal against [[Leeds United A.F.C.|Leeds United]] and braces against [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]] and [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]], but missed out to Leeds' [[Chris Wood (footballer, born 1991)|Chris Wood]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Zohore nominated for Player of the Month |url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/zohore-nominated-for-sky-bet-championship-potm-3615820.aspx |publisher=Cardiff City F.C. Official Site |date=9 March 2016 |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref> His 12 goals for Cardiff saw him as the top goalscorer for the season, and he was awarded a contract keeping him at the club until 2020.<ref>{{cite news |title=Kenneth Zohore: Danish striker agrees new Cardiff City deal |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39751940 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 April 2017 |accessdate=28 April 2017}}</ref> At the end of the season, he was awarded the club's Young Player of the Year award.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/aron-gunnarsson-big-winner-cardiff-12968468|title=Aron Gunnarsson is the big winner in Cardiff City's 2016/17 awards as Kenneth Zohore is also honoured|last=Booth|first=Dominic|date=30 April 2017|work=|accessdate=30 April 2017|publisher=Wales Online}}</ref>
====2017–18==== Zohore's form at the end of the previous season attracted interest from several clubs with [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]], with an original bid of £6 million,<ref name="Hullbid">{{cite web |url=http://www.hulldailymail.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/hull-city-see-10m-bid-335212 |title=Hull City see £10m bid for Kenneth Zohore rejected by Cardiff City |work=Hull Daily Mail |author=William Jackson |date=16 August 2017 |accessdate=20 August 2017}}</ref> and [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] both having bids rejected by Cardiff.<ref name="nodeal">{{cite web |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/no-deal-place-cardiff-citys-13499799 |title=No deal in place for Cardiff City's Kenneth Zohore to join Brighton as striker prepares for Wolves clash |publisher=WalesOnline |author=Matthew Southcombe |date=19 August 2017 |accessdate=20 August 2017}}</ref> Manager Neil Warnock later commented that Zohore was not for sale and would only leave the club if "I have a heart attack and another manager takes over."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40641182 |title=Kenneth Zohore: Cardiff striker not for sale says manager Neil Warnock |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 July 2017 |accessdate=20 August 2017}}</ref> Zohore scored his first goal of the season in the opening match, the only goal of the game in a 1–0 victory over [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]] on 5 August 2017.<ref name="nodeal"/> Following a nine-game goal drought, Zohore scored a brace against [[Leeds United A.F.C.|Leeds United]] on 26 September, in a 3–1 win, before suffering an ankle injury which kept him out until the Christmas Period.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff City 3–1 Leeds United |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41315213 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 September 2017 |accessdate=26 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Kenneth Zohore: Cardiff striker on the mend but not ready to play |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42263556 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 December 2017 |accessdate=20 December 2017}}</ref> He returned to the side, replacing [[Omar Bogle]] in a 2–0 defeat at [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] on 23 December, before scoring his fourth of the season against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] on [[Boxing Day]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Bolton Wanderers 2–0 Cardiff City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42375402 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 December 2017 |accessdate=23 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff City 2–4 Fulham |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42406713 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 December 2017 |accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref> The new year saw Zohore score 5 goals, including winners against [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] and [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff City 1–0 Bristol City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43101660 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 February 2018 |accessdate=15 June 2018}}</ref> Cardiff finished in 2nd place, gaining promotion to the [[Premier League]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff City 0–0 Reading |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43938851 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 May 2018 |accessdate=15 June 2018}}</ref>
====2018-19==== Zohore started the [[2018–19 Cardiff City F.C. season|2018–19]] season as Cardiff's lead striker against [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]], however, a string of injuries and bad form saw Zohore in and out of the squad. He scored his first [[Premier League]] goal, in a 2–1 win at [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on 9 February.<ref>{{cite news |title=Southampton 1–2 Cardiff City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47099258 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=9 February 2019 |accessdate=9 February 2019}}</ref>
==International career== In May 2018 he was named in Denmark’s preliminary 35-man [[Denmark national football team|squad]] for the [[2018 World Cup]] in [[Russia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/amp/news/revealed-every-world-cup-2018-squad-23-man-preliminary-lists/oa0atsduflsv1nsf6oqk576rb|title=Revealed: Every World Cup 2018 squad - 23-man & preliminary lists & when will they be announced? - Goal.com|publisher=}}</ref> However, he did not make the final 23.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.socceroos.com.au/news/confirmed-denmark-cut-ex-arsenal-star-fifa-world-cup-squad|title=Confirmed: Denmark cut ex-Arsenal star from FIFA World Cup squad|website=Socceroos}}</ref>

| nationalteam-update = }} '''Joshua Murphy''' (born 24 February 1995) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]]. He scored on his professional debut in a [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] match against [[Watford F.C.|Watford]]. He is the twin brother of professional footballer [[Jacob Murphy]].
==Club career== ===Norwich City=== Murphy, along with his twin brother, Jacob, first played football together from the age of seven<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/news/2013-14/oct/barclays-u21-jacob-murphy-interview.html |title=Barclays U21s: Murphy's twin ambition for Norwich |publisher=Premier League Official Website |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=30 October 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229135507/http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/news/news/2013-14/oct/barclays-u21-jacob-murphy-interview.html |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> and eventually, they both joined [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] as an under-12 in 2006.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dream chance for nine Norwich City hopefuls|url=http://www.pinkun.com/norwich-city/dream_chance_for_nine_norwich_city_hopefuls_1_847433|publisher=The Pink UN|date=31 March 2011|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref> It was announced on 31 March 2011, that Josh and his twin brother Jacob joined the club's academy ahead of a new season.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dream chance for nine Norwich City hopefuls|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/sport/norwich-city-fc/dream_chance_for_nine_norwich_city_hopefuls_1_847433|publisher=Eastern Daily Press 34|date=31 March 2011|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref>
====2012–13 season==== Murphy's first involvement in the Norwich first-team came on 26 September 2012 when he was named as an unused substitute in the club's 1–0 [[2012–13 Football League Cup|Football League Cup]] victory over [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Norwich City 1 – 0 Doncaster Rovers|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19645223|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 September 2012|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref> He was a part of the Norwich City youth team who won the [[2012–13 FA Youth Cup]] where he scored in the final against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Rik Sharma |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2324979/Norwichs-twin-wingers-Josh-Jacob-Murphy-ready-cause-havoc-Premier-League.html |title=Norwich's twin wingers Josh and Jacob Murphy are ready to cause havoc in the Premier League |work=Daily Mail|date=15 May 2013 |accessdate=24 September 2013}}</ref> Murphy signed his first professional contract for Norwich City alongside his twin brother [[Jacob Murphy|Jacob]] on 4 January 2013.<ref name=FirstContract>{{cite web|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/sport/norwich-city-fc/twins_jacob_and_josh_murphy_sign_professional_contracts_with_norwich_city_1_1783241 |title=Twins Jacob and Josh Murphy sign professional contracts with Norwich City – Norwich City FC – Eastern Daily Press |publisher=Edp24.co.uk |accessdate=24 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/murphy-twins-sign-pro-579399.aspx |title=MURPHY TWINS SIGN PRO |publisher=Norwich City F.C. |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=4 January 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229132346/http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/murphy-twins-sign-pro-579399.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
====2013–14 season==== He made his professional debut on 24 September 2013, replacing [[Bradley Johnson]] in the 67th minute of Norwich's [[2013–14 Football League Cup|Football League Cup]] match against [[Watford F.C.|Watford]], with Norwich 2–0 down. He scored his first professional goal in the 77th minute to pull the score back to 2–1. Norwich eventually went on to win 3–2 in extra time.<ref name=Debut>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24122104 |title=Watford v Norwich|publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=24 September 2013}}</ref> He made his league debut on 2 November 2013 as a half-time substitute for [[Steven Whittaker]] in Norwich's 7–0 league defeat against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]]. Then, in December 2013, both Josh and Jacob both signed a three year contract with the club.<ref name="TheDuoatNorwichCity">{{cite news|title=Norwich City twins Josh and Jacob Murphy sign new long-term deals at the club|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/sport/norwich-city-fc/norwich_city_twins_josh_and_jacob_murphy_sign_new_long_term_deals_at_the_club_1_3143370|publisher=Eastern Daily Press 24|date=23 December 2013|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref>
His first senior start was in the [[FA Cup]] for Norwich City against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]]. He set up the first goal and was eventually substituted for his brother [[Jacob Murphy]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Manchester City 7, Norwich City 0|url=http://www.pinkun.com/norwich-city/manchester_city_7_norwich_city_0_1_2960960|publisher=The Pink UN|accessdate=2 November 2013}}</ref> In 2014, Josh was awarded Professional of the Year in the West Norfolk Sports Awards, as well as the special achievement award.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/west-norfolk-awards-30-jan-14-1328828.aspx |title=JOSH WINS LOCAL AWARD |publisher=Norwich City F.C. |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=30 January 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229141331/http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/west-norfolk-awards-30-jan-14-1328828.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/20140510-norwich-city-academy-awards-1544990.aspx |title=2013–14 NORWICH CITY ACADEMY AWARDS |publisher=Norwich City F.C. |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=10 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229142734/http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/20140510-norwich-city-academy-awards-1544990.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> Soon under management of [[Neil Adams (footballer)|Neil Adams]], Josh had a long run in the first team, making appearance for Norwich City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/20140323-josh-murphy-norwich-city-1506462.aspx |title=MURPHY LOOKING TO PUSH ON |publisher=Norwich City F.C. |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=23 April 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229141334/http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/20140323-josh-murphy-norwich-city-1506462.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
====2014–15 season==== Following Norwich City's relegation to the Championship, Murphy made his first start of the 2014–15 season, where he played 90 minutes and scored twice, which his twin brother Jacob provided one of the two goals Josh scored, in a 3–1 win over [[Crawley Town F.C.|Crawley Town]] in the second round of the League Cup.<ref>{{cite news|title=Norwich City 3 – 1 Crawley Town|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28847093|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 August 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref> Murphy's first league goal game in a 3–1 win for Norwich over [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] on 27 September 2014.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lewis Grabban and Josh Murphy goals send Norwich past Blackpool|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/sep/27/blackpool-norwich-championship-match-report|work=The Guardian|accessdate=28 September 2014}}</ref>
====Wigan Athletic (loan)==== With his first team opportunities limited, Murphy joined [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] on a month's loan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wiganlatics.co.uk/news/article/wigan-athletic-sign-josh-murphy-on-loan-from-norwich-city-2338521.aspx|title=JOSH MURPHY SIGNS ON LOAN|publisher=Wigan Athletic F.C.|date=16 March 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402130226/http://www.wiganlatics.co.uk/news/article/wigan-athletic-sign-josh-murphy-on-loan-from-norwich-city-2338521.aspx|archivedate=2 April 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Murphy made his Wigan Athletic debut, coming on as a substitute for [[Jermaine Pennant]] in the 55th minutes, in a 2–0 loss against Watford on 17 March 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wiganlatics.co.uk/news/article/report-wigan-athletic-0-watford-2-championship-deeney-2341350.aspx|title=REPORT: WIGAN ATHLETIC 0 WATFORD 2|publisher=Wigan Athletic F.C.|date=17 March 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150705184016/http://www.wiganlatics.co.uk/news/article/report-wigan-athletic-0-watford-2-championship-deeney-2341350.aspx|archivedate=5 July 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref> Murphy's five appearance at Wigan Athletic soon earned a loan extension until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news|title=Norwich winger Josh Murphy extendeds his loan at Wigan|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11709/9807828/murphy-stays-with-wigan|publisher=Sky Sports|date=16 April 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015}}</ref> However, Murphy was unable to help Wigan Athletic survive relegation and returned to his parent club.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wiganlatics.co.uk/news/article/wigan-athletic-players-contracts-summer-2015-retained-list-2461399.aspx|title=PLAYERS' CONTRACTS UPDATE|publisher=Wigan Athletic F.C.|date=18 May 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150520183627/http://www.wiganlatics.co.uk/news/article/wigan-athletic-players-contracts-summer-2015-retained-list-2461399.aspx|archivedate=20 May 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
====2015–16 season==== ====Milton Keynes Dons (loan)==== [[File:Fulham FC v MK Dons (26146337761).jpg|thumb|upright|Murphy (right) playing for [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]] in 2016]]
On 21 August 2015, Murphy joined Championship club [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]] on a season-long loan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mkdons.com/news/article/murphy-makes-dons-move-josh-murphy-josh-murphy-norwich-city-josh-murphy-mk-dons-2635969.aspx|title=Murphy makes Dons move|publisher=Milton Keynes Dons F.C. |accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref> He scored the winning goal on his debut in a 2–1 win over Cardiff City in the League Cup 2nd Round. On 26 September 2015, Murphy scored his first league goal in the 1–3 home defeat to [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]].
On 3 May 2016, Murphy was named Milton Keynes Dons Players' Player of the Year 2015–16.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mkdons.com/news/article/martin-named-player-of-the-year-mk-dons-david-martin-mk-dons-mk-dons-player-of-the-year-3094149.aspx|title=Martin named Player of the Year|publisher=Milton Keynes Dons F.C. |accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref> In total, Murphy made 46 appearances for the club, scoring 7 goals in all competitions. Murphy finished the season as the Dons' joint top goalscorer and achieved the most assists.
===Cardiff City===
On 12 June 2018, Murphy joined [[Premier League]] side [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on a 4-year contract for an undisclosed fee, believed to be around £11 million.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44438532 |title=Josh Murphy: Cardiff City sign Norwich City winger |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 June 2018 |accessdate=12 June 2018}}</ref> He made his debut for the club on the opening day of the [[2018–19 Premier League|2018–19]] season as a substitute in place of [[Nathaniel Mendez-Laing]] during a 2–0 defeat to [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/live/football/44875934 |title=Bournemouth 2–0 Cardiff City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 August 2018 |accessdate=11 August 2018}}</ref> Following a short spell on the sidelines, Murphy scored his first Cardiff goal against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]], followed by his second in 4–2 win over [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff City 1–2 Burnley |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45616872 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 September 2018 |accessdate=30 September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff City 4–2 Fulham |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45847412 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 October 2018 |accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref>
==International career== Both Josh and Jacob were called up by the [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] in October 2012<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/england-u-18s-call-for-josh-murphy-422113.aspx |title=ENGLAND U-18S CALL FOR MURPHY TWINS |publisher=Norwich City F.C. |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=11 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229140134/http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/england-u-18s-call-for-josh-murphy-422113.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> and made their U18's debut in a 1–0 win over [[Finland national under-19 football team|Finland U19]] on 13 November 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/murphys-shine-for-young-lions-486236.aspx |title=MURPHYS SHINE FOR YOUNG LIONS |publisher=Norwich City F.C. |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=14 November 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229140056/http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/murphys-shine-for-young-lions-486236.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
Then in early 2013, Both Josh and Jacob were called up by [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/february2013-call-ups-611887.aspx |title=TETTEY GETS NORWAY CALL |publisher=Norwich City F.C. |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=22 January 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229140859/http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/february2013-call-ups-611887.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> and their U19's debut in a 3–1 win over [[Denmark national under-19 football team|Denmark U19]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/round-up-feb-2013-642705.aspx |title=INTERNATIONAL ROUND-UP |publisher=Norwich City F.C. |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=7 February 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229141235/http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/round-up-feb-2013-642705.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> Then on 14 November 2013, Josh scored his first England U19 goal in a 4–1 win over [[Hungary national under-19 football team|Hungary U19]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Norwich City winger Josh Murphy stars with goal and two assists for England Under-19s in Hungary|url=http://www.pinkun.com/norwich-city/norwich_city_winger_josh_murphy_stars_with_goal_and_two_assists_for_england_under_19s_in_hungary_1_3004122|publisher=The Pink UN|date=14 November 2013|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref>
In late 2014, Jacob was called by [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/20140901-september-internationals-preview-1890976.aspx |title=CITY INTERNATIONAL WATCH: PREVIEW |publisher=Norwich City F.C. |accessdate=29 December 2014 |date=1 September 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141229142816/http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/20140901-september-internationals-preview-1890976.aspx |archivedate=29 December 2014 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> and scored on his debut on 5 September 2014, in a 6–0 win over [[Romania national under-20 football team|Romania U20]].<ref>{{cite news|title=England Under 20 6–0 Romania Under 20: Goal fest gives new boss Aidy Boothroyd a perfect start as Roy Hodgson watches on|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2745943/England-Under-20-6-0-Romania-Under-20-Goal-fest-gives-Aidy-Boothroyd-perfect-start.html|work=Daily Mail|date=6 September 2014|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref>
==Personal life== Murphy was born in [[Wembley]], London.<ref name=Hugman/>
The twins spoke about their close bonds and being there for each other.<ref name="TheDuoatNorwichCity"/> Their parents and younger brother live in [[Downham Market]] and run the Arbuckles restaurant.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mum is the word for Norwich City starlet Josh Murphy|url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/news/mum_is_the_word_for_norwich_city_starlet_josh_murphy_1_2809818|work=Eastern Daily Press 24|date=26 September 2013|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref>
While on the pitch, former manager [[Chris Hughton]] instructed the twins to wear different coloured boots so that he could tell them apart.<ref>{{cite news|title=Norwich City's Murphy twins wear different boots to help boss|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25685868|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 December 2014|accessdate=29 December 2014}}</ref> His uncle is former [[Ipswich Town]] footballer [[Tommy Parkin]].<ref name=parkinsNephews>{{cite news | last = Roger | first = James | title = Who is Jacob Murphy? Five things you need to know about Coventry City FC's new signing | newspaper = Coventry Telegraph | location = Coventry | language = English | date = 15 August 2015 | url = https://www.coventrytelegraph.net/sport/football/football-news/who-jacob-murphy-five-things-9862814 | access-date = 18 April 2018}}</ref>

{{lead too short|date=June 2017}} {{EngvarB|date=April 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Callum Paterson | image = Callum Paterson.png | fullname = Callum Thomas Owen Paterson<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.efl.com/siteassets/efl-documents/efl-professional-retain-list--free-transfers---2017-18.pdf |title=Club list of registered players: As at 19th May 2018: Cardiff City |publisher=English Football League |format=PDF |page=12 |accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1994|10|13}} | birth_place = [[London]], England<ref name="London">{{cite journal |last=Kiddie |first=Paul |title=Heart of Midlothian Pen Pics |journal=Scottish Communities League Cup Programme |volume=Semi-final Inverness v Hearts |date=January 2013 |page=P28}}</ref> | height = | position = [[Utility player]] | currentclub = [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] | clubnumber = 13 | youthyears1 = 2004–2010 | youthclubs1 = [[Tynecastle Boys Club]] | youthyears2 = 2010–2012 | youthclubs2 = [[Heart of Midlothian F.C. Under-20s and Academy|Heart of Midlothian]] | years1 = 2012–2017 | clubs1 = [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Heart of Midlothian]] | caps1 = 137 | goals1 = 33 | years2 = 2017– | clubs2 = [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] | caps2 = 59 | goals2 = 14 <!-- When updating please update club-update and stats table below not just Infobox.--> | nationalyears1 = 2012 | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalteam1 = [[Scotland national under-18 football team|Scotland U18]] | nationalyears2 = 2012 | nationalcaps2 = 1 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalteam2 = [[Scotland national under-19 football team|Scotland U19]] | nationalyears3 = 2012–2015 | nationalteam3 = [[Scotland national under-21 football team|Scotland U21]] | nationalcaps3 = 12 | nationalgoals3 = 2 | nationalyears4 = 2016– | nationalteam4 = [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] | nationalcaps4 = 11 | nationalgoals4 = 0 | club-update = 17:08, 9 March 2019 (UTC) | ntupdate = 22 September 2018 (UTC) }} '''Callum Thomas Owen Paterson''' (born 13 October 1994)<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.uefa.com/uefanationsleague/season=2019/teams/player=250053754/index.html | title=Callum Paterson | publisher=[[Uefa]] | work=uefa.com | accessdate=23 September 2012}}</ref> is a professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Premier League]] club [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] and [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]]. Paterson started his career with [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Heart of Midlothian]], helping them win promotion to the [[Scottish Premiership]] in 2015. He moved to Cardiff City in 2017, and helped them win promotion to the Premier League in 2018.
Paterson mainly played for Hearts as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|right-back]], but was also sometimes used as a [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]]. Since moving to Cardiff he has mainly played as a [[midfielder]], but will occasionally play higher up the pitch to help aid the attack. He has been praised for his work rate, pace, aerial ability, positioning, and goalscoring prowess.
==Early life== Paterson's father is [[Scottish people|Scottish]] and his mother is from [[Zimbabwe]]. His maternal grandfather is South African.<ref name="edinburghnews"/> Paterson was born in [[London]] and moved from there to Scotland when he was three years old.<ref name="edinburghnews">{{cite web|url=http://www.edinburghnews.scotsman.com/sport/football/hearts/callum-paterson-reveals-he-s-eligible-for-four-countries-1-3626686|title=Callum Paterson reveals he's eligible for four countries|work=Edinburgh News (Scotsman)|date=6 December 2014}}</ref><ref name = "London"/> He grew up in [[South Queensferry]]<ref name="Queensferry">{{cite web | url=http://www.linlithgowgazette.co.uk/news/local-headlines/queensferry-teen-s-debut-for-hearts-1-2423582 | title=Queensferry teen's debut for Hearts | publisher=Linlithgow Gazette | work=linlithgowgazette.co.uk | date=21 July 2012 | accessdate=4 August 2012}}</ref> where he attended [[Queensferry High School]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.linlithgowgazette.co.uk/sport/local-sport/cousins-snapped-up-for-senior-squads-1-276891 | title=Cousins snapped up for senior squads | publisher=Linlithgow Gazette | work=linlithgowgazette.co.uk | date=16 July 2010 | accessdate=12 December 2012}}</ref> He is the cousin of fellow footballer [[Michael Travis (footballer)|Michael Travis]].<ref name = "Queensferry"/>
==Club career== ===Heart of Midlothian=== Paterson began his career as a youth player at [[Tynecastle F.C.|Tynecastle]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/hearts-starlet-callum-paterson-cant-1273229 | title=I can't believe I'm about to face Steven Gerrard, says Hearts starlet | publisher=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]] | work=dailyrecord.co.uk | date=22 August 2012 | accessdate=23 September 2012}}</ref> before joining [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Heart of Midlothian]] in 2010.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.hydc.co.uk/callum_paterson.html | title=Callum Paterson | publisher=Heart of Midlothian Youth Development Committee | work=hydc.co.uk | accessdate=4 August 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130527201218/http://www.hydc.co.uk/callum_paterson.html | archivedate=27 May 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21370530 | title=Foot injury ends Callum Paterson's season | publisher=[[BBC Sport]] | work=bbc.co.uk | date=7 February 2013 | accessdate=7 February 2013}}</ref> A member of the club's Under-20 side<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.heartsfc.co.uk/page/Squad/DevelopmentTeamDetail/0,,10289,00.html | title=U20 team | publisher=[[Heart of Midlothian F.C.]] | work=heartsfc.co.uk | accessdate=4 August 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110901234010/http://www.heartsfc.co.uk/page/Squad/DevelopmentTeamDetail/0%2C%2C10289%2C00.html | archivedate=1 September 2011 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> he was promoted to the first team during pre-season in the summer of 2012 and made his first team debut on 14 July, in a friendly against [[Raith Rovers F.C.|Raith Rovers]] where he scored the first goal of the game.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.heartsfc.co.uk/articles/20120714/match-report-raith-rovers-0-3-hearts_2241384_2847597 | title=Match Report: Raith Rovers 0–3 Hearts | publisher=[[Heart of Midlothian F.C.]] | accessdate=4 August 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120927071330/http://www.heartsfc.co.uk/articles/20120714/match-report-raith-rovers-0-3-hearts_2241384_2847597 | archivedate=27 September 2012 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Having impressed during these pre-season fixtures,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.scotsman.com/sport/football/spl/hearts-boss-backs-young-talent-1-2448792 | title=Hearts boss backs young talent | publisher=[[Johnston Press]] | work=[[The Scotsman]] | date=3 August 2012 | accessdate=4 August 2012}}</ref> on 4 August he made his [[Scottish Premier League]] (SPL) debut aged 17, in a 2–0 win over [[St Johnstone F.C.|St Johnstone]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19025830 | title=Hearts 2 – 0 St Johnstone | publisher=[[BBC]] | work=BBC Sport | date=4 August 2012 | accessdate=4 August 2012}}</ref> He made his European debut on 23 August, in a 1–0 defeat to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] at [[Tynecastle Stadium|Tynecastle]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19279553 | title=Hearts 0–1 Liverpool | publisher=[[BBC]] | work=BBC Sport | date=23 August 2012 | accessdate=23 August 2012}}</ref>
On 31 August 2012, Paterson signed a new contract extending his stay with the club until 2015.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.heartsfc.co.uk/articles/20120831/contract-for-callum_2241384_2906740 | title=Contract for Callum | publisher=[[Heart of Midlothian F.C.]] | work=heartsfc.co.uk | date=31 August 2012 | accessdate=1 September 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203074744/http://www.heartsfc.co.uk/articles/20120831/contract-for-callum_2241384_2906740 | archivedate=3 December 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> On 22 September 2012, he scored his first two Career goals<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-match-reports/spl-dundee-united-0-hearts-1338414 | title=Hearts kid Callum Paterson gets first career goals as they demolish Dundee United | publisher=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]] | work=dailyrecord.co.uk | date=22 September 2012 | accessdate=23 September 2012}}</ref> in a 3–0 win over [[Dundee United F.C.|Dundee Utd]] in the [[Scottish Premier League|SPL]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19615258 | title=Dundee Utd 0–3 Hearts | publisher=[[BBC]] | work=BBC Sport | date=22 September 2012 | accessdate=23 September 2012}}</ref> On 22 January 2013,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.heartsfc.co.uk/articles/20130124/injury-blow-for-callum_2241384_3051618 | title=Injury blow for Callum | publisher=[[Heart of Midlothian F.C.]] | work=heartsfc.co.uk | date=24 January 2013 | accessdate=26 January 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203063253/http://www.heartsfc.co.uk/articles/20130124/injury-blow-for-callum_2241384_3051618 | archivedate=3 December 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> Paterson suffered ligament damage to his foot<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11781/8477655/ | title=Callum Paterson out until next season after surgery on injured foot | publisher=[[Sky Sports]] | work=skysports.com | date=7 February 2013 | accessdate=7 February 2013}}</ref> in training that ruled him out of the [[Scottish League Cup]] Semi-final against [[Inverness Caledonian Thistle F.C.|Inverness]] that weekend.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11790/8430279/Hearts-teenager-Callum-Paterson-to-miss-semi-final-and-will-have-scan-on-his-ankle | title=Hearts teenager Callum Paterson to miss semi-final and will have scan on his ankle | publisher=[[Sky Sports]] | work=skysports.com | date=24 January 2013 | accessdate=26 January 2013}}</ref> The injury required surgery and ultimately ruled him out for the remainder of the season.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/blow-for-hearts-as-striker-callum-paterson-1591668 | title=Blow for Hearts as striker Callum Paterson is ruled out for the rest of the season | publisher=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]] | work=dailyrecord.co.uk | date=7 February 2013 | accessdate=7 February 2013}}</ref> During his debut season Paterson made twenty seven appearances, scoring four times<ref>{{Soccerbase season|65785|2012|accessdate=1 July 2013}}</ref> In doing so he played as a [[Defender (association football)#Full back|right-back]], [[midfielder]] and as a [[Striker (association football)|striker]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://sport.stv.tv/football/clubs/hearts/191436-hearts-boss-says-callum-paterson-will-be-a-full-time-striker-after-double/ | title=Hearts boss says Callum Paterson will be a full-time striker after double | publisher=[[Scottish Television|STV]] | work=sport.stv.tv | date=22 September 2012 | accessdate=23 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-match-reports/spl-dundee-united-0-hearts-1338938 | title=Hearts starlet Callum Paterson set for extended run up front | publisher=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]] | work=dailyrecord.co.uk | date=23 September 2012 | accessdate=23 September 2012}}</ref> with the latter being the position he played in before joining Hearts.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.scotsman.com/edinburgh-evening-news/football/hearts/hearts-youngster-callum-paterson-may-retain-striking-berth-against-dundee-united-1-2535109 | title=Hearts youngster Callum Paterson may retain striking berth against Dundee Unite | publisher=[[Edinburgh Evening News]] | work=scotsman.com | date=23 September 2012 | accessdate=23 September 2012}}</ref>
On 11 August 2013, Paterson scored his first goal of the 2013–14 campaign, when he headed home the only goal in the [[Edinburgh derby]] against [[Hibernian F.C.|Hibernian]] at Tynecastle.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23565318 | title=A Callum Paterson header gave Hearts a vital victory and bragging rights in a frantic and edgy Edinburgh derby. | publisher=[[BBC Sport]] | work=bbc.co.uk/sport | date=11 August 2013 | accessdate=6 May 2014}}</ref> On 27 April 2014, Paterson scored a brace against city rivals Hibernian in a 2–1 win. A week later he scored again in a 5–0 win over [[Kilmarnock F.C.|Kilmarnock]] and also scored three days later against [[Partick Thistle F.C.|Partick Thistle]]. Hearts were relegated at the end of the season, but immediately won promotion by winning the [[2014–15 Scottish Championship]]. In their first season back in the top flight, Hearts finished third in the [[2015–16 Scottish Premiership]] and qualified for European competition.
During the summer of 2016, Patterson was subject to interest from several [[EFL Championship]] sides, with Hearts rejecting two bids from [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Callum Paterson: Hearts reject new Wigan bid for full-back |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37181276 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 August 2016 |accessdate=24 August 2016}}</ref> Despite the interest, he stayed at the club, managing to score 9 goals in 20 appearances, before suffering a serious knee injury on 27 December, which ruled him out for six to nine months.<ref>{{cite news |title=Callum Paterson: Hearts right-back sidelined for six to nine months |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38450959 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 December 2016 |accessdate=28 December 2016}}</ref> Despite missing the last few months of the season, Paterson managed to pick up the club's Young Player of the Year Award.<ref name=YPLOY/>
===Cardiff City=== On 7 June 2017, Paterson agreed a three-year deal with [[EFL Championship]] club [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Callum Paterson: Scotland defender joins Cardiff City on three-year deal |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40189922 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 June 2016 |accessdate=7 June 2016}}</ref> The knee injury suffered at Hearts kept him out of the first two months of the season, making his playing return for the [[Cardiff City F.C. Academy|Under-23 side]] in a 4–0 win over [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]], on 18 September.<ref>{{cite news |title=U23 Match Report Burnley 0–4 Cardiff City |url=https://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/2017/september/match-report-for-burnley-u23-vs-cardiff-city-u23-on-18-sep-17/ |publisher=Cardiff City Football Club |date=18 September 2017 |accessdate=18 September 2017}}</ref> On 21 October, Paterson returned to the first team, making his debut in a 1–0 win over [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]], before scoring his first goal for the club, the winner at [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]], a month later.<ref>{{cite news |title=Middlesbrough 0–1 Cardiff City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41618274 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 October 2017 |accessdate=22 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Barnsley 0–1 Cardiff City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41978131 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 November 2017 |accessdate=23 November 2017}}</ref> Cardiff manager, [[Neil Warnock]] moved Paterson into a central midfield position in the new year, later stating the reasoning behind the move was because he couldn't defend.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42682884 |title=Callum Paterson: Cardiff 'wobble' out of way, says Scotland international |date=15 January 2018 |accessdate=13 February 2018 |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Neil Warnock reveals why he won't actually play 'defender' Callum Paterson in defence |url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/neil-warnock-reveals-wont-actually-14419127 |publisher=South Wales Echo |date=16 March 2018 |accessdate=17 March 2018}}</ref> Following his move to the new position, Paterson scored a brace against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on 13 January and found the back of the net three times in March.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff City 4–0 Sunderland |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42587431 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 January 2018 |accessdate=17 March 2018}}</ref> He continued his good form throughout the rest of the season, scoring 10 goals, ending as the club's top goal scorer in the league, as they were promoted to the [[Premier League]]. Paterson was also voted Young Player of the Season by the Cardiff fans.<ref>{{cite news |title=Awards 2018: The Winners |url=https://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/2018/may/awards-2018/ |publisher=Cardiff City F.C. |date=6 May 2018 |accessdate=6 May 2018}}</ref>
Paterson played his first Premier League game against [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] on the opening day of the season. As Cardiff struggled for goals, Paterson was moved into a central forward role, where he scored his first Premier League goal in a 4–2 win over [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff City 4–2 Fulham |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45847412 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 October 2018 |accessdate=20 October 2018}}</ref>
==International career== Paterson earned caps at both [[Scotland national under-18 football team|under-18]] and [[Scotland national under-19 football team|under-19]] level in 2012 before establishing himself as a regular in [[Scotland national under-21 football team|Scotland under-21]] squads.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fitbastats.com/scotlandu21/player.php?playerid=545|title=Scotland U21 player Callum Paterson |website=FitbaStats|accessdate=28 October 2018}}</ref>
On 10 November 2014, manager [[Gordon Strachan]] called Paterson into the [[Scotland national football team|senior Scottish squad]] for the first time after [[Phil Bardsley]] pulled out of the squad injured, ahead of a European qualifier against the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] and a friendly against [[England national football team|England]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Hearts defender Callum Paterson called up by Scotland|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29989566|accessdate=10 November 2014|work=BBC Sport|date=10 November 2014}}</ref>
He made his senior debut for Scotland on 29 May 2016 in a 1–0 friendly defeat against [[Italy national football team|Italy]].
