|nationalyears4 = 2008– |nationalteam4 = [[Iceland national football team|Iceland]] |nationalcaps4 = 81 |nationalgoals4 = 2 |club-update = 17:10, 9 March 2019 (UTC) |ntupdate = 15 November 2018 }} '''Aron Einar Malmquist Gunnarsson''' (born 22 April 1989) is an Icelandic professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for Welsh {{English football updater|CardiffC}} club [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] and [[Captain (association football)|captains]] the [[Iceland national football team|Icelandic national team]]. He can play either as a [[Midfielder#Defensive midfielder|defensive midfielder]] or a [[Midfielder#Central midfielder|central midfielder]].
He began his career at [[Þór Akureyri]], and played one match for Dutch club [[AZ (football club)|AZ]] before joining England's [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] in 2008. After 133 matches and 7 goals in three seasons for them, he transferred to Cardiff City, where he was a runner-up in the [[2012 Football League Cup Final]] and played in the [[2013–14 Premier League]].
Aron plays for [[Iceland national football team|Iceland]] at international level, having made his senior debut in 2008, and has earned over 80 caps for them. He has been Iceland's [[Captain (association football)|captain]] since mid-2012, captaining the team to the quarter-finals at their first major tournament, [[UEFA Euro 2016]].
==Club career== ===Early career=== Born in [[Akureyri]], Aron began playing football in his native Iceland on gravel pitches. During the winter months, snow and ice left football pitches unplayable and Aron instead played [[handball]], making three appearances in the Icelandic handball League at the age of fifteen.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/jun/09/aron-gunnarsson-iceland-midfield-leader |title=Aron Gunnarsson: Iceland's midfield leader and long-throw star |newspaper=The Guardian |author=Kristján Jónsson |date=9 June 2016 |accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref> He began his football career with local side [[Þór Akureyri]] in 2005 and, after investment in indoor pitches by the Icelandic government, began to train all year round. At the age of seventeen, Aron moved to the Netherlands, joining the youth academy at [[AZ (football club)|AZ]].<ref name="dragons">{{cite web |url=https://www.theplayerstribune.com/en-us/articles/there-be-ice-dragons-here |title=There Be Ice Dragons Here |publisher=The Players' Tribune |author=Aron Gunnarsson |date=4 June 2018 |accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref> After initially struggling with homesickness, he settled in the country and made his debut for the club during the 2007–08 season.<ref name="Gunnarsson, Aron Einar"/>
===Coventry City=== Aron signed for English [[EFL Championship|Championship]] team [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]] on 17 June 2008, signing a three-year contract for an undisclosed fee.<ref>{{cite news |title=Coventry set to sign Gunnarsson |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/coventry_city/7454902.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 June 2008 |accessdate=17 June 2008}}</ref> He made his debut on the opening day of the Championship season against [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]], where Coventry won 2–0.<ref>{{cite news|title=Coventry City 2 – 0 Norwich City |url=http://www.ccfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10269~43657,00.html |publisher=Coventry City F.C |date=9 August 2008 |accessdate=9 August 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207185557/http://www.ccfc.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10269~43657%2C00.html |archivedate=7 December 2008 }}</ref> He scored his first career goal on 14 February 2009 in an [[FA Cup]] match against [[Premier League]] side [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Blackburn 2–2 Coventry |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/7872196.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 February 2009 |accessdate=14 February 2009}}</ref> During his time at Coventry, Aron attracted [[Premier League]] interest leading Coventry City to offer him an improved deal on 12 March.<ref>{{cite news |title=Hall is offered new Coventry deal |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/coventry_city/7940294.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 March 2009 |accessdate=12 March 2009}}</ref> His first league goal came against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Crystal Palace 1–1 Coventry |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/7977127.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 April 2009 |accessdate=7 April 2009}}</ref> At the end of his first season in England, Aron was voted the Coventry City Supporter's Player of the Year as well as the club's Community Award.<ref>{{cite news |title=Gunnarsson wins Sky Blues award |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/coventry_city/8033160.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 May 2009 |accessdate=5 May 2009}}</ref>
The following season, Aron changed his shirt number from 12 to 17, to mirror the squad number of his brother, who is a professional handball player.<ref>{{cite news|title=News: Squad numbers announced |url=http://www.ccfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10269~1728846,00.html |publisher=Coventry City F.C |date=21 July 2009 |accessdate=10 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314014616/http://www.ccfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10269~1728846%2C00.html |archivedate=14 March 2012 }}</ref> The following season, he continued as a vital part of the Coventry midfield, throughout the season he made 42 appearances and scored one goal against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Middlesbrough 1 – 1 Coventry |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8632725.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 April 2010 |accessdate=24 April 2010}}</ref>
Coventry City started the 2010–11 season strongly looking like they were pushing for play-off places. Aron opened his season's goal scoring count with a goal against newly promoted, [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]], despite Coventry losing 3–1.<ref>{{cite news |title=Millwall 3 – 1 Coventry |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8941283.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 August 2010 |accessdate=28 August 2008}}</ref> After three years at Coventry, he scored his first goal at Coventry City's home ground, the [[Ricoh Arena]], against [[Preston North End F.C.|Preston North End]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Coventry 1 – 2 Preston |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/9021245.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 September 2010 |accessdate=25 September 2010}}</ref> Three days later, Aron scored his second goal in two matches against [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.|Doncaster Rovers]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Coventry 2 – 1 Doncaster |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/9031717.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 September 2010 |accessdate=28 September 2010}}</ref> He was out of contract at the end of the season and on 10 December, Aron stated his desire to stay at Coventry.<ref>{{cite news |title=Aron Gunnarsson keen to sign new deal at Coventry City |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/coventry_city/9275863.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 December 2010 |accessdate=10 December 2010}}</ref> However the following week, he received his first red card of his career against [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Coventry 1 – 2 Norwich |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/9283523.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 December 2010 |accessdate=18 December 2010}}</ref> However a deal for a new contract couldn't be reached between his agent and Coventry, and at the end of the season the club gave him a deadline date to agree to stay.<ref>{{cite news |title=Westwood, King & Gunnarsson get Coventry City deadline |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/coventry_city/9483766.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 May 2011 |accessdate=12 May 2011}}</ref>
However, due to Aron and his agent not being able to reach an agreement with Coventry, he was linked with moves away and his agent confirmed that fellow Championship outfit [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] were favourites to sign him.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff City 'among favourites' to sign Iceland star Aron Gunnarsson from Coventry City |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/footballnation/football-news/2011/07/05/cardiff-city-among-favourites-to-sign-iceland-star-aron-gunnarsson-from-coventry-city-91466-28992897/ |newspaper=South Wales Echo |first=Terry |last=Phillips |date=5 July 2011 |accessdate=5 July 2011}}</ref>
===Cardiff City=== [[File:Aron Gunnarsson.jpg|thumb|200|Aron playing for [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] in 2012]] On 8 July 2011, Aron agreed a three-year deal with fellow Championship team [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on a free transfer, as the fifth signing for new manager [[Malky Mackay]]. Coventry were due compensation via him being under the age of 24.<ref>{{cite news|title=Aron Gunnarsson joins Cardiff City on free transfer|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/14089640|accessdate=4 July 2016|publisher=BBC Sport|date=8 July 2011}}</ref>
He made his debut on 7 August in the first match of the new season, playing the full 90 minutes in the 1–0 away win over [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]].<ref>{{cite news |title=West Ham 0 – 1 Cardiff |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/14356630.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 August 2011 |accessdate=7 August 2011}}</ref> In his second match, Aron limped off with an ankle injury after only ten minutes against [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]], the injury sidelining him for a week.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff City midfielder Aron Gunnarsson sidelined for a week |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/14523831.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=16 August 2011 |accessdate=16 August 2011}}</ref> He returned after the September international break, insisting his injury was behind him.<ref>{{cite news |title=Aron Gunnarsson ready to put injury woes behind him at Cardiff City |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/footballnation/cardiff-city-fc/2011/09/09/aron-gunnarsson-ready-to-put-injury-woes-behind-him-at-cardiff-city-91466-29389513/? |newspaper=South Wales Echo |first=Steve |last=Tucker |date=9 September 2011 |accessdate=9 September 2011}}</ref> On 22 October, Aron scored two goals in a 5–3 victory against [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]], receiving the [[man of the match]] award.<ref>{{cite news|title=Gunnar: The win was the important thing |url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10335~2490796,00.html |publisher=Cardiff City F.C |date=22 October 2011 |accessdate=10 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120911001508/http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10335~2490796%2C00.html |archivedate=11 September 2012 }}</ref>
Aron played the entirety of the [[2012 Football League Cup Final]], as City were beaten 3–2 on penalties after by [[Premier League]] club [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] at [[Wembley Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Cardiff City 2–2 Liverpool: Liverpool win 3–2 on pens|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17093419|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 February 2012|accessdate=31 May 2013}}</ref>
Aron scored Cardiff's first goal in the Premier League on 25 August 2013, against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] in a 3–2 win.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23744629|title= Cardiff 3 Man City 2|date=25 August 2013|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=29 August 2013 }}</ref> In June 2015 he signed a new contract with the club, until the summer of 2018.<ref>{{cite news|title=Gunnarsson signs extension|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32972706|publisher=BBC Sport|date=2 June 2015}}</ref>
Following his return from [[Euro 2016]], Aron was linked with a move away from the Welsh capital, with [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] and [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] claimed to be interested. However, Cardiff City manager, [[Paul Trollope]], described him as "a very important player" to the club.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff City insist Aron Gunnarsson is 'very important player to us' amid Derby County and Norwich City links |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/cardiff-city-insist-aron-gunnarsson-11764918 |work=Wales Online |first=Phil |last=Smith |date=18 August 2016 |accessdate=18 August 2016}}</ref> His performances under Trollope and his eventual replacement [[Neil Warnock]] saw him awarded the club's Player of the Year award at the end of the season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/aron-gunnarsson-big-winner-cardiff-12968468 |title=Aron Gunnarsson is the big winner in Cardiff City's 2016/17 awards as Kenneth Zohore is also honoured |publisher=WalesOnline |author=Dominic Booth |date=30 April 2017 |accessdate=2 May 2017}}</ref>
The following season, Aron failed to nail down a consistent place in the starting eleven, due to a number of injuries throughout the first half of the season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Aron Gunnarsson: Cardiff boss Neil Warnock hopeful of midfielder's fitness |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41595104 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 October 2017 |accessdate=12 October 2017}}</ref> Despite his injury problems, Cardiff offered him a new contract, which was later rejected by the player.<ref>{{cite news |title=Aron Gunnarsson: Iceland midfielder to leave Cardiff City after rejecting deal |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42181533 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 November 2017 |accessdate=30 November 2017}}</ref> Aron returned to the side for the final run-in, where he scored the winning goal against [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] and ultimately helped Cardiff gain promotion to the [[Premier League]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff City 2–1 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43762401 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 April 2018 |accessdate=15 June 2018}}</ref>
In July 2018, Aron signed a new one-year deal.<ref>{{cite news |title=Confirmed: Aron Gunnarsson signs new City deal |url=https://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/2018/july/aron-gunnarsson-signs-new-city-deal/ |publisher=Cardiff City Official Site |date=9 July 2018 |accessdate=9 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44769640|title=Aron Gunnarsson: Cardiff City midfielder signs new contract|date=9 July 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
In March 2019 it was announced that Aron would leave the club at the end of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47622311|title=Aron Gunnarsson: Cardiff City midfielder set to leave at end of season|date=19 March 2019|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:2014-05-30 Austria - Iceland football match, Aron Gunnarsson 0265-crop.jpg|thumb|Right|Aron playing for [[Iceland national football team|Iceland]] in 2012.]] Aron made his international debut for [[Iceland national football team|Iceland]] on 2 February 2008.<ref>{{cite web|title=Aron Einar Gunnarsson |url=http://www.ksi.is/mot/motalisti/felagsmadur/?pLeikmadurNr=148732&pListi=4 |publisher=[[KSÍ]] |language=Icelandic |accessdate=15 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131017234158/http://www.ksi.is/mot/motalisti/felagsmadur/?pLeikmadurNr=148732&pListi=4 |archivedate=17 October 2013 }}</ref> Aron was called up to the [[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship|2011 European Under-21 Championship]] [[Iceland national under-21 football team|Iceland]] squad, which took place in [[Denmark]]. In the first match, Iceland beat hosts [[Denmark national under-21 football team|Denmark]] 3–1. This was followed with a 2–0 loss to [[Belarus national under-21 football team|Belarus]], where Aron was sent off.<ref>{{cite news|title=Belarus get the better of Iceland |url=http://www.uefa.com/under21/matches/season=2011/round=2000002/match=2003388/postmatch/report/index.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612214437/http://www.uefa.com/under21/matches/season%3D2011/round%3D2000002/match%3D2003388/postmatch/report/index.html |dead-url=yes |archivedate=12 June 2011 |publisher=UEFA |date=11 June 2011 |accessdate=11 June 2011 }}</ref> The two losses saw Iceland go out of the tournament via a tie breaker. Aron has been a regular player in the senior side since debuting despite helping the U-21 side when they qualified for the [[UEFA Under-21 Championship]].
Aron was named as the permanent [[Captain (association football)|captain]] of the national team before a friendly match against the [[Faroe Islands national football team|Faroe Islands]] in August 2012 at the young age of 23, ahead of his 29th cap.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mbl.is/sport/fotbolti/2012/08/14/aron_einar_skipadur_fyrirlidi/ |title=Aron Einar skipaður fyrirliði|publisher=[[Morgunblaðið]] |date=14 August 2012 |accessdate=7 February 2013 |language=Icelandic}}</ref> Under his captaincy, Iceland qualified for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Second Round|play-off round]] of [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification|FIFA World Cup qualification]] for the first time,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://icelandreview.com/news/2013/10/17/world-cup-playoff-iceland-poses-problems|title=World Cup Playoff in Iceland Poses Problems|date=17 October 2013|work=Iceland Review}}</ref> where they lost 2–0 on aggregate to [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/24907602|title=Croatia 2–0 Iceland|date=19 November 2015|publisher=BBC}}</ref>
On 10 October 2014, Aron scored his first senior international goal in Iceland's 3–0 away win against [[Latvia national football team|Latvia]] in [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/season=2016/matches/round=2000446/match=2013849/index.html|title=Iceland down Latvia to maintain winning run|date=10 October 2014|publisher=UEFA}}</ref> He scored again in a 2–1 defeat of the [[Czech Republic national football team|Czech Republic]] on 12 June 2015.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33116122|title=Iceland 2–1 Czech Rep.|date=12 June 2015|publisher=BBC}}</ref> On 6 September, he was sent off in the last minute of a goalless draw at [[Laugardalsvöllur]] in [[Reykjavík]] against [[Kazakhstan national football team|Kazakhstan]], a result which put Iceland into their first major international tournament.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Stefánsson|first1=Stefán|title=Draw sends Iceland through to UEFA EURO 2016|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/qualifiers/season=2016/matches/round=2000446/match=2013998/postmatch/report/index.html|accessdate=6 September 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=6 September 2015}}</ref>
Aron captained Iceland at their first major international tournament, [[UEFA Euro 2016]] in France. After their first match, a shock 1–1 draw with [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] in [[Saint-Étienne]], opposing skipper [[Cristiano Ronaldo]] refused to trade shirts with him.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wright|first1=Chris|title=Iceland's Aron Gunnarsson finally gets his hands on a Cristiano Ronaldo shirt|url=http://www.espnfc.co.uk/blog/the-toe-poke/65/post/2898652/aron-gunnarsson-finally-gets-his-hands-on-a-cristiano-ronaldo-shirt|accessdate=3 July 2016|publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 June 2016}}</ref> Iceland finished second in their group, after beating [[Austria national football team|Austria]] and drawing against [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]], and then knocked out [[England national football team|England]] in the round of 16.<ref>{{cite news |title=England 1 Iceland 2: Fairytale continues as Hodgson's men crash out |url=http://www.fourfourtwo.com/news/england-1-iceland-2-fairytale-continues-hodgsons-men-crash-out |website=[[FourFourTwo]] |date=27 June 2016 |accessdate=28 June 2016}}</ref> They were defeated by [[France national football team|France]], 5–2, in the quarter-final. Aron played in all five games.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/season=2016/teams/team=58/squad/index.html|title=UEFA EURO 2016 - History - Iceland – UEFA.com|last=uefa.com|website=UEFA.com|language=en|access-date=18 June 2018}}</ref>
In May 2018 he was named in Iceland’s [[Iceland national football team|23 man squad]] for the [[2018 World Cup]] in [[Russia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.goal.com/en/news/world-cup-squad-injured-gylfi-sigurdsson/17guw991qjit61qqhhfn9lyhon|title=Injured Gylfi Sigurdsson in Iceland's World Cup squad - Goal.com|website=www.goal.com}}</ref>
==Personal life== His older brother [[Arnór Þór Gunnarsson]] plays [[handball]] for the [[Iceland national handball team|Icelandic national team]].<ref>{{cite news|title=THE GUNNARSSON BROTHERS: A HANDBALL-FOOTBALL FAIRYTALE|url=http://www.eurohandball.com/article/026260/The+Gunnarsson+brothers%3A+A+handball-football+fairytale|accessdate=14 August 2016|publisher=European Handball Federation|date=3 July 2016}}</ref>

'''Gregory Richard "Greg" Cunningham''' (born 31 January 1991) is an Irish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a left back for [[Premier League]] side [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] and the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland national team]].
==Career==
===Manchester City=== [[File:Greg Cunningham.JPG|thumbnail|Cunningham playing for [[Manchester City F.C. Reserves and Academy|Manchester City Reserves]] in 2010]] Born in [[Galway]], [[County Galway]],<ref name="Hugman2010-11"/> Cunningham began his career with Cregmore FC. In 2004, he joined [[Mervue United A.F.C.|Mervue United]] before earning a contract in the [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] [[Manchester City F.C. Reserves and Academy|Academy]]. Cunningham made his [[first team]] debut for Manchester City as a 46th minute [[substitute (association football)|substitute]] in a 4–2 victory over [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]] in the [[FA Cup]] on 24 January 2010 where he played on the left side of the City defence.<ref name="Scunthorpe 2 - 4 Man City">{{cite news|first=Sam|last=Lyon|title =Scunthorpe 2 – 4 Man City|url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/8468696.stm|work=BBC Sport|date=24 January 2010|accessdate=24 January 2010}}</ref> Cunningham made his first [[Premier League]] appearance on 11 April 2010 against [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] as a substitute for [[Adam Johnson (footballer)|Adam Johnson]] in the final minutes of the game.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8609889.stm|title=Man City 5 – 1 Birmingham|first=Chris|last=Bevan|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=11 April 2010|date=11 April 2010}}</ref> Cunningham made his second [[Premier League]] appearance on 9 May 2010 against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] as a substitute for Johnson, just 2 minutes of the final minutes of the game.<ref>{{cite news|title=West Ham 1 – 1 Man City|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8666056.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|date=9 May 2010|accessdate=12 July 2012}}</ref> On 26 August 2010, Cunningham made his European debut in Europa League Qualifiers Second Leg against [[FC Politehnica Timișoara|Politehnica Timișoara]], coming on as a 54th-minute substitute for [[Nigel de Jong]] in a 2–0 win. On 22 September 2010, Cunningham made his first start for the club and played 90 minutes in a 2-1 loss against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] in the [[2010–11 Football League Cup|League Cup]].
====Leicester City (loan)==== On 21 October 2010, Cunningham joined [[Football League Championship|Championship]] side [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] on [[loan (sports)|loan]] until January 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10274~2192184,00.html |title=Foxes Sign Man City's Cunningham |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |work=lcfc.com |accessdate=21 October 2010 |date=21 October 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101025200526/http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0%2C%2C10274~2192184%2C00.html |archivedate=25 October 2010 |df= }}</ref> On 23 October 2010, Cunningham made his debut for the club in a 2–0 loss against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] where he played the full 90 minutes. Cunningham became a regular left-back in the starting eleven and made 12 starts. On 1 January 2011, Cunningham fractured his [[tibia]] in a challenge with [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]]'s [[Liam Rosenior]]. Rosenior was sent off and Cunningham had to be substituted in a 1–0 win for Leicester and he was ruled out of action for up to four months, which ended his loan spell at Leicester City.<ref>{{cite news|title=Greg Cunningham out for four months with broken leg|url=http://www.thisisleicestershire.co.uk/Greg-Cunningham-months-broken-leg/story-12061039-detail/story.html|publisher=This is Leicestershire|date=3 January 2011|accessdate=12 July 2012}}</ref> After the match, [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]] say his injury was 'a complete accident' and said:
{{cquote|"To be fair, there was absolutely no intention from Liam Rosenior and it was just a very unfortunate incident. Our physio team worked immediately on the injury, comforted Greg and they were superb. However, the good start to the New Year is also a bad start for us as we have lost Greg Cunningham to a broken leg."<ref>{{cite news|title=Foxes in Cunningham blow|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/match_reaction/0,19764,11065_3283944,00.html|publisher=Sky Sports|date=1 January 2011|accessdate=12 July 2012}}</ref>}}
====Nottingham Forest (loan)==== On 25 October 2011, Cunningham joined Championship side [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] on loan until 31 December after an injury crisis at the club left them desperately on short defensive options.<ref>{{cite news|title=Manchester City's Greg Cunningham loaned to Nottingham Forest|url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/News/Team-news/2011/October/Greg-Cunningham-loaned-to-Nottingham-Forest|publisher=Manchester City F.C.|work=mcfc.co.uk|first=Tim|last=Oscroft|date=25 October 2011|accessdate=25 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Cunningham Checks In |url=http://www.nottinghamforest.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10308~2492606,00.html |publisher=Nottingham Forest F.C. |work=nottinghamforest.co.uk |date=25 October 2011 |accessdate=25 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111028012357/http://www.nottinghamforest.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10308~2492606%2C00.html |archivedate=28 October 2011 |df= }}</ref> After his move to Nottingham Forest, Cunningham says he expected to make an impact for the club and was looking forward to playing regularly for the club<ref>{{cite news|title=Cunningham raring to go|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/7265710/|publisher=Sky Sports|date=25 October 2011|accessdate=12 July 2012}}</ref> Nottingham Forest duo [[Lee Camp (footballer)|Lee Camp]] and [[Ishmael Miller]] agreed with Cunningham's expectations.<ref>{{cite news|title=Forest boosted by signing|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/7267521/|publisher=Sky Sports|date=26 October 2011|accessdate=12 July 2012}}</ref> On 29 October 2011, Cunningham made his debut for the club in a 1–0 loss against Hull City before being substituted early in the second-half. On 1 November 2011, Cunningham played 90 minutes in a 1–0 win over [[Reading F.C.|Reading]]. Since making his debut, Cunningham became a regular in the starting eleven, playing at left back.
On 29 December, Cunningham's loan was extended until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news|title=Reds Strike Deal For Greg|url=http://www.nottinghamforest.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10308~2560442,00.html|date=29 December 2011|accessdate=31 March 2012|publisher=Nottingham Forest F.C.|work=nottinghamforest.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Reds extend Cunningham loan|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/7400900/|publisher=British Sky Broadcasting|work=Sky Sports|date=29 December 2011|accessdate=31 March 2012}}</ref> After his loan was extended, manager [[Steve Cotterill]] says he would want to sign Cunningham on a permanent basis, only if the money can be found in the near future.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cunningham continues to impress|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/7402458/|publisher=Sky Sports|date=30 December 2011|accessdate=12 July 2012}}</ref> After his loan spell ended, Cotterill praised Cunningham (among the loan signing) for helping the club pull away from the relegation zone and stay in the Championship next season.<ref>{{cite news|title=Cotterill praises loan impact|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/7649695/|publisher=Sky Sports|date=4 April 2012|accessdate=12 July 2012}}</ref>
===Bristol City=== The following season, Cunningham told [[BBC Sport]] he intended to leave Manchester City to further his career.<ref>{{cite news|title=Greg Cunningham ready for Manchester City exit|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18721399|publisher=BBC Sport|date=5 July 2012|accessdate=12 July 2012}}</ref> On 5 July 2012, Cunningham signed a four-year contract at [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]], for an undisclosed fee.<ref>{{cite news|title=Manchester City defender Greg Cunningham joins Bristol City|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/18721392|work=BBC Sport|date=5 July 2012|accessdate=5 July 2012}}</ref>
Cunningham made his debut on the opening game of the season, in a 1–0 loss against [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]]. Then, in a 2–1 win over [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]], on 18 September 2012, Cunningham received a heavy tackle from [[Tyrone Barnett]] after Barnett made a reckless challenge on him, which resulted in Cunningham being stretched off and Barnett being booked. After the match, [[Derek McInnes]] believes that Barnett should have been sent-off for the challenge<ref>{{cite news|title=Bristol City manager Derek McInnes bemoans 'reckless' tackles|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19647453|publisher=BBC Sport|date=19 September 2012|accessdate=8 August 2013}}</ref> Cunningham was ruled out for two months after rupturing his tendon.<ref>{{cite news|title=Greg Cunningham: Bristol City defender out for two months|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19647458|publisher=BBC Sport|date=22 September 2012|accessdate=8 August 2013}}</ref> In mid-December, Cunningham recovered from the injury and made his return in a 2–0 loss against [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] on 15 December 2012.<ref>{{cite news|title=Greg Cunningham could make Bristol City return this weekend|url=http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/Greg-Cunningham-make-Bristol-City-return-weekend/story-17577880-detail/story.html|publisher=Bristol Post|date=13 December 2012|accessdate=8 August 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131231000839/http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/Greg-Cunningham-make-Bristol-City-return-weekend/story-17577880-detail/story.html|archivedate=31 December 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 29 January 2013, Cunningham scored his first goal for Bristol City against [[Watford F.C.|Watford]], a cross that had looped over [[Almunia|Manuel Alumunia]] and found its way into the back of the net.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bristol City 2–0 Watford|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21137530|publisher=BBC Sport|date=29 January 2013|accessdate=8 August 2013}}</ref> Since his recovery from injury, Cunningham continued to retain his first team place in the left-back position, though sometimes plays in the left-midfield, but unfortunately, the club was relegated to League One.
===Preston North End=== Bristol City gave Cunningham permission to speak to Preston North End after accepting an undisclosed bid, he spent the weekend with Preston in Scotland at a training camp before the deal was completed on 27 July 2015.<ref>{{cite news|title=Preston Close to Cunningham Signing|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33674016|work=BBC Sport|date=27 July 2015|accessdate=27 July 2015}}</ref>
On 24 July 2017, Cunningham was appointed captain of Preston until such a time as [[Tom Clarke (footballer, born 1987)|Tom Clarke]] became fit again.<ref>{{cite news|title=Greg Named Stand-In Captain|url= https://www.pnefc.net/news/2017/july/greg-named-stand-in-captain/|work=Preston North End FC|date=24 July 2017|accessdate=24 July 2017}}</ref>
===Cardiff City===
On 13 June 2018, Cunningham joined [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] for an undisclosed fee, believed to be around £4 million signing a 3-year contract.<ref>{{cite news|title=Greg Cunningham: Cardiff City sign Preston North End defender|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44380823|work=BBC Sport|date=13 June 2018|accessdate=13 June 2018}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:FIFA WC-qualification 2014 - Austria vs Ireland 2013-09-10 - Greg Cunningham 01.JPG|thumbnail|Cunningham with the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] in 2013]] Cunningham had been capped by the Republic of Ireland at youth level before being called up to the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|senior]] international squad by manager [[Giovanni Trapattoni]] on 22 February 2010 for a friendly against [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]].<ref name="Hugman2010-11"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2010/0222/republicofireland_brazil.html|title=Trapattoni names 23-man squad for Brazil|date=22 February 2010|publisher=RTÉ Sport|accessdate=22 February 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100224073852/http://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2010/0222/republicofireland_brazil.html|archivedate=24 February 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 28 May 2010, Cunningham made his debut for Ireland in a 3–0 win against [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] at the [[RDS Arena|RDS]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2010/0527/ireland_cunninghamg.html|title=Greg Cunningham set to make Ireland debut|date=27 May 2010|publisher=RTÉ Sport|accessdate=28 May 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/irish/8712258.stm|title=Rep of Ireland 3–0 Algeria|date=28 May 2010|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=28 May 2010}}</ref>

{{Spanish name|Camarasa|Ferrando}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Víctor Camarasa | image = | fullname = Víctor Camarasa Ferrando | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1994|5|28|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Meliana]], Spain | height = {{convert|1.83|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} | position = [[Midfielder#Central midfielder|Midfielder]] | currentclub = [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]]
(on loan from [[Real Betis|Betis]]) | clubnumber = 21 | youthyears1 = 2001–2011 | youthclubs1 = [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] | youthyears2 = 2011–2012 | youthclubs2 = [[CD Alcoyano|Alcoyano]] | youthyears3 = 2012–2013 | youthclubs3 = [[Levante UD|Levante]] | years1 = 2013–2014 | clubs1 = [[Atlético Levante UD|Levante B]] | caps1 = 27 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2014–2017 | clubs2 = [[Levante UD|Levante]] | caps2 = 61 | goals2 = 4 | years3 = 2016–2017 | clubs3 = → [[Deportivo Alavés|Alavés]] (loan) | caps3 = 31 | goals3 = 3 | years4 = 2017– | clubs4 = [[Real Betis|Betis]] | caps4 = 24 | goals4 = 1 | years5 = 2018– |clubs5 = → [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] (loan) |caps5 = 25 | goals5 = 4 | nationalyears1 = 2014–2017 | nationalteam1 = [[Spain national under-21 football team|Spain U21]] | nationalcaps1 = 4 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | club-update = 17:11, 9 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Víctor Camarasa Ferrando''' (born 28 May 1994) is a Spanish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for Welsh club [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on loan from [[Real Betis]] as a [[Midfielder#Central midfielder|central midfielder]]. ==Club career== ===Levante=== Born in [[Meliana]], [[Valencian Community]], Camarasa joined local [[Valencia CF]]'s youth categories in 2001, aged seven. Ten years later he was released, and eventually finished his formation with neighbouring [[Levante UD]], making his senior debuts with the [[Atlético Levante UD|reserve side]] in the [[2012–13 Segunda División B|2012–13 season]], in [[Segunda División B]].[http://www.mundodeportivo.com/20130912/fc-barcelona/barca-levante-filial-fichajes-victor-camarasa_54381344850.html El Barça sigue a Víctor Camarasa (Barça follow Víctor Camarasa)]; [[Mundo Deportivo]], 12 September 2013 (in Spanish) On 7 December 2013, Camarasa played his first official game with the main squad, starting in a 0–1 away loss against [[Recreativo de Huelva]] for [[2013–14 Copa del Rey|the campaign]]'s [[Copa del Rey]].[http://www.marca.com/eventos/marcador/futbol/2013_14/copa/dieciseisavos/ida/rec_lev/ Ruymán decide 'a puerta cerrada' (Ruymán decides 'behind closed doors')]; [[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]], 7 December 2013 (in Spanish) Two days later he signed a new six-year deal with the club,[http://www.plazadeportiva.com/ver/14193/el-levante-renueva-a-sus-perlas--jason-y-victor-camarasa.html El Levante renueva a sus perlas, Jason y Victor Camarasa (Levante renew their gems, Jason and Victor Camarasa)]; Plaza Deportiva, 9 December 2013 (in Spanish) and he scored his first goal on the 17th, helping turn the Cup deficit in his team's favour by netting the last in the 4–0 home win.[http://www.marca.com/eventos/marcador/futbol/2013_14/copa/dieciseisavos/vuelta/lev_rec/ Vendaval granota hacia octavos (''Granota'' blizzard en route to last-16)]; Marca, 17 December 2013 (in Spanish) Camarasa made his [[La Liga]] debut on 4 January 2014, coming on as a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Simão Mate Junior|Simão Mate]] in a 0–2 away loss against [[Valencia CF]].[http://www.marca.com/2014/01/04/futbol/1adivision/1388868940.html ¡Che, qué bueno que viniste! (''Che'', so good of you to come!)]; Marca, 4 January 2014 (in Spanish) In July he was promoted to the first team,[http://levanteud.lasprovincias.es/noticias/201407/31/victor-camarasa-mendilibar-quiere-20140731175508.html Víctor Camarasa: «Mendilibar quiere algo distinto a lo que quería Caparrós» (Víctor Camarasa: "Mendilibar wants something different from what Caparrós wanted")]; [[Las Provincias]], 31 July 2014 (in Spanish) and was made a starter by new manager [[José Luis Mendilibar]]. On 4 October 2014, Camarasa scored his first goal in the top flight, netting his side's second in a 3–3 draw at [[SD Eibar]].[http://www.espnfc.com/spanish-primera-divisi%C3%B3n/match/402566/eibar-levante/report Piovaccari levels thriller late on]; [[ESPN FC]], 4 October 2014 On 11 August 2016, after [[2015–16 La Liga|suffering relegation]], he was loaned to [[Deportivo Alavés]] also in the top tier, for one year.[http://www.deportivoalaves.com/noticia/camarasa-potencia-calidad-y-llegada-para-el-centro-del-campo Camarasa, potencia, calidad y llegada para el centro del campo (Camarasa, power, skill and definition for the midfield)]; Deportivo Alavés, 11 August 2016 (in Spanish) ===Betis=== On 29 June 2017, Camarasa signed a five-year contract with fellow league club [[Real Betis]].[http://realbetisbalompie.es/en/noticias/last-news/9427/el-real-betis-incorpora-victor-camarasa Real Betis signs Víctor Camarasa]; Real Betis, 29 June 2017 He scored his first competitive goal for them on 18 December, helping close a 2–0 away defeat of neighbouring [[Málaga CF]].{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/eventos/marcador/futbol/2017_18/la-liga/jornada_16/mga_bet/|title=Y al séptimo día, resucitó|trans-title=And on the seventh day, they came back to life|newspaper=Marca|last=Morán|first=Miguel Ángel|language=es|date=18 December 2017|accessdate=14 August 2018}} On 9 August 2018, Camarasa joined [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on loan for the [[2018–19 Premier League|2018–19 season]].{{cite web|url=https://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/2018/august/deadline-day--victor-camarasa-joins-on-loan/|title=Victor Camarasa signs on loan|publisher=Cardiff City F.C|date=9 August 2018|accessdate=9 August 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/45126885|title=Victor Camarasa: Cardiff City confirm midfielder loan deal|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=9 August 2018|accessdate=9 August 2018}} He made his [[Premier League]] debut nine days later, playing 76 minutes in a 0–0 home draw against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/45153217|title=Cardiff City 0–0 Newcastle United|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Pritchard|first=Dafydd|date=18 August 2018|accessdate=18 August 2018}} His first goal came on 2 September, but in a 2–3 loss to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] also at the [[Cardiff City Stadium]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/45312124|title=Cardiff City 2–3 Arsenal|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Pearlman|first=Michael|date=2 September 2018|accessdate=22 December 2018}} ==Career statistics== {{updated|9 March football team|Ivory Coast]] in 2012 | fullname = Souleymane Bamba<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.efl.com/documents/professional-retained-report-2015-16549-3151378.pdf |title=EFL: Retained list: 2015/16 |publisher=English Football League |page=29 |format=PDF |accessdate=29 June 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161202052144/http://www.efl.com/documents/professional-retained-report-2015-16549-3151378.pdf |archivedate=2 December 2016 }}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1985|1|13}} | birth_place = [[Ivry-sur-Seine]], France | height = {{height|m=1.90}} | position = [[Defender (association football)|Centre-back]] | currentclub = [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] | clubnumber = 22 | youthyears1 = 1996–2004 | youthclubs1 = [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]] | years1 = 2004–2006 | caps1 = 1 | goals1 = 0 | clubs1 = [[Paris [[Trabzonspor]] | years6 = 2014–2015 | caps6 = 1 | goals6 = 0 | clubs6 = [[U.S. Città di Palermo|Palermo]] | years7 = 2015 | caps7 = 19 | goals7 = 1 | clubs7 = → [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] (loan) | years8 = 2015–2016 | caps8 = 32 | goals8 = 4 | clubs8 = [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] | years9 = 2016– | caps9 = 100 | goals9 = 10 | clubs9 = [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] |
