nationalcaps1 = 20 | nationalgoals1 = 3 | club-update = 17:13, 9 March 2019 (UTC) | ntupdate = 18 November 2018 }} '''David Wayne "Junior" Hoilett''' (born 5 June 1990) is a Canadian professional [[association football]] player who plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] and the [[CMNT|Canadian national team]].
He signed for English club [[Blackburn Rovers]] at the age of 13, and was loaned to [[SC Paderborn 07|SC Paderborn]] and [[FC St. Pauli]] in the German [[2. Bundesliga]]. He made his Rovers debut in 2009 and played three full [[Premier League]] seasons for them before a transfer to [[Queens Park Rangers]]. Hoilett spent four years at the [[Loftus Road]] club – alternately in the Premier League and [[EFL Championship|Championship]] – before moving to Cardiff on the expiration of his contract.
Hoilett made his senior international debut for [[Canada men's national soccer team|Canada]] in 2015. He was part of their squad at the [[2017 CONCACAF Gold Cup]].
==Club career==
===Blackburn Rovers Academy=== Hoilett was born in [[Brampton]], [[Ontario]], and played several sports as a child before settling on football at age 11.<ref name=lancs>{{cite news |last1=Cryer |first1=Andy |title=Hoilett: I've made it at Blackburn Rovers the hard way |url=https://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/5046588.hoilett-ive-made-it-at-blackburn-rovers-the-hard-way/ |accessdate=22 January 2019 |work=Lancashire Telegraph |date=8 March 2010}}</ref> In the same year, he travelled the world with his club and gained attention at a tournament in Wales; he turned down [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] for [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] as he believed he had more chance of breaking into the first team at the latter.<ref name=lancs/> After moving to England, he attended [[St Bede's Roman Catholic High School, Blackburn|St Bede's Roman Catholic High School]] in [[Blackburn]].<ref name=lancs/><ref>{{cite news |title=Premier League Under 16 Schools’ Cup for Girls’ Final |url=http://www.esfa.co.uk/news/?2015/04/28/094110/premier-league-under-16-schools-cup-for-girls-final |accessdate=22 January 2019 |publisher=English Schools Football Association |date=28 April 2015}}</ref> As he was initially unable to earn a work permit to play in the United Kingdom, Blackburn loaned him to German clubs to help him earn one in the future.<ref name=lancs/>
====SC Paderborn (loan)==== Hoilett made his debut for [[SC Paderborn 07|SC Paderborn]] (on [[loan (sports)|loan]]) against [[Kickers Offenbach]], coming on as a [[substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Sven Lintjens]] in a 3–2 victory on 3 February 2008, aged 17.<ref name="Zwei Aussetzer in der Defensive">{{cite news | title = Zwei Aussetzer in der Defensive | url = http://www.scpaderborn07.de/scpaderborn07/2-Home/3698,Zwei-Aussetzer-in-der-Defensive.html | publisher = SC Paderborn | date = 3 February 2008 | language = German | accessdate =27 March 2008}}</ref> Hoilett's first match in the starting eleven was against [[TSG 1899 Hoffenheim|1899 Hoffenheim]] on 9 March 2008.<ref name="Beste Torchancen vergeben">{{cite news|title=Beste Torchancen vergeben |url=http://www.scpaderborn07.de/scpaderborn07/38-Saison/3820,Beste-Torchancen-vergeben.html |language=German |publisher=SC Paderborn |date= |accessdate=27 March 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719083808/http://www.scpaderborn07.de/scpaderborn07/38-Saison/3820%2CBeste-Torchancen-vergeben.html |archivedate=19 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Hoilett scored his only goal of his loan campaign on 18 May 2008 against [[Borussia Mönchengladbach]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Paderborn vs. Borussia M'gladbach 2 – 3|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2008/05/18/germany/2-bundesliga/sc-paderborn-07-ev/borussia-monchengladbach/470135/|publisher=SoccerWay.com|accessdate=31 January 2012|date=18 May 2008}}</ref> in what would be his final game for the club.
Paderborn were later relegated, ending the [[2007–08 2. Bundesliga]] season in 17th position.<ref>{{cite web|title=Germany 2007/08|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesd/duit08.html|publisher=rsssf.com|accessdate=31 January 2012}}</ref>
====FC St. Pauli (loan)==== Hoilett was loaned to another German club in the [[2. Bundesliga]], [[FC St. Pauli]], for the [[2008–09 2. Bundesliga]] season. He made his debut for the [[Hamburg]]-based side against [[SpVgg Greuther Fürth]] on 22 August 2008. He scored six times during his loan campaign with braces against [[Alemannia Aachen]] and [[F.C. Hansa Rostock|Hansa Rostock]], as well as individual goals against [[TSV 1860 München|1860 München]] and [[1. FC Kaiserslautern]]. His final game would come in the form of a 1–0 loss against [[Rot Weiss Ahlen]] on 3 May 2009. St. Pauli finished the season in eighth position.<ref>{{cite web|title=Germany 2008/09|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesd/duit09.html|publisher=rsssf.com|accessdate=31 January 2012}}</ref>
===Blackburn Rovers=== In January 2009, Hoilett's home club Blackburn applied for him to receive a [[work permit]] for him to play football in England.<ref name="Hoilett Fight For Work Permit">{{cite news | title = Teen ace in permit fight | first = Andy | last = Cryer | url = http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/search/4427012.Teen_ace_in_permit_fight/ | publisher = Lancashire Telegraph | date = 9 June 2009 | accessdate = 14 June 2009}}</ref> In the summer of 2009, Hoilett was granted a work permit on appeal, allowing him to continue his fledgling career in England at the [[Premier League]] level with Blackburn.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.kicker.de/news/fussball/2bundesliga/startseite/artikel/511053/ | title = Hoilett zurück auf der Insel | language = German | publisher = kicker.de | accessdate = 9 July 2012 | date = 6 July 2009}}</ref>
[[File:Junior Hoilett.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Hoilett before the match between Blackburn and Arsenal at Ewood Park on September 17, 2011]]
He scored his first and second goals for Blackburn since his full-time return to the club in only his third game, in a pre-season friendly against non-League club [[Leigh Genesis F.C.|Leigh Genesis]]. He also earned Rovers a penalty in that game. His first competitive goal for Rovers came in a 3–1 [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] win at [[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham]] on 25 August 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/8203195.stm |title=Gillingham 1 – 3 Blackburn |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 August 2009 |accessdate=26 August 2009}}</ref>
Hoilett was involved in Blackburn's dramatic [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] win against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on 2 December 2009. Coming on as a second half substitution, he won an extra-time penalty which [[Benni McCarthy]] converted to put Rovers 3–2 up, but then missed a golden chance late on to seal victory before [[Paulo Ferreira]] equalised in the 122nd minute. However, Hoilett converted the crucial fifth penalty to help Rovers to the 4–3 shootout win and a place in the semi-finals. He then started his first league match on 12 December 2009 against [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]], playing the full 90 minutes in a 0–0 draw at the [[KC Stadium]]. On 25 February 2010, with his contract due to expire in June 2010, Hoilett ended media speculation regarding his future at the club, by signing a new two-and-a-half year deal with Blackburn, keeping him at the club until the summer of 2012. On 9 May, he scored a header in a win over [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] at [[Villa Park]] on the final day of the season, although the goal was later recorded as a [[Richard Dunne]] own goal. Hoilett made his first Premier League appearance of the [[2010–11 Premier League|2010–11 season]] on 21 August 2010 by coming on for [[Nikola Kalinić]] in the 84th minute in a 2–1 defeat at [[St Andrew's (stadium)|St Andrew's]] against [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.rovers.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10303~1976874,00.html | title = Junior agrees new deal | publisher = Blackburn Rovers | date = 25 February 2010 | accessdate = 9 July 2012 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120329034014/http://www.rovers.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10303~1976874,00.html | archive-date = 29 March 2012 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
He scored his first goal of the 2010–11 season in the 1–0 victory over [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] in the [[FA Cup]] third round.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rovers.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0,,10303~54887,00.html |title=Junior scores 1st 2010/11 season goal vs QPR |publisher=Blackburn Rovers |accessdate=9 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111014225535/http://www.rovers.co.uk/page/MatchReport/0%2C%2C10303~54887%2C00.html |archivedate=14 October 2011 |df= }}</ref>
Hoilett scored his first league goal on 23 January 2011 in a 2–0 home victory against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] at [[Ewood Park]], converting in the 47th minute from a Nikola Kalinić assist. On 12 February 2011, he made his 40th Premier League appearance for Blackburn when he featured against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] at Ewood Park in a goalless draw, and was replaced at half-time due to a slight hamstring strain by [[Morten Gamst Pedersen]]. On 5 March, he scored his third goal of the season in a 3–2 defeat against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] in the 65th minute, away at [[Craven Cottage]]. He replaced by debutant [[Rubén Rochina]] on 82 minutes. His next goal came in the following game, a last gasp equaliser coming from a header against [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] at Ewood Park in a 2–2 draw. On 9 April 2011, he scored in the 1–1 draw versus Birmingham City at Ewood Park on half-time, but he unfortunately got injured in the 68th minute, being replaced by Australian [[Brett Emerton]].
He scored his fifth league goal of the season with an individual goal, in a 3–2 win against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] at [[Molineux Stadium]] on the last day of the season. On 11 September 2011, in a game between Blackburn and [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]], he was involved in a collision with [[Mark Schwarzer]] which resulted a head injury for Hoilett. He was eventually stretched off and Schwarzer received a yellow card. Hoilett scored a controversial second's goal in a match as Blackburn drew with [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] 3–3 after teammate Morten Gamst Pedersen seemed to dribble the ball straight from a corner before firing in a low cross for Hoilett to head home from two yards.<ref name="3 Wigan–3 Blackburn">{{cite news | title = Wigan 3–3 Blackburn | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/15704787.stm | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 19 November 2011 | accessdate =19 November 2011}}</ref>
In January 2012, Hoilett was named one of the 13 players to watch in 2012 by world football governing body [[FIFA]].<ref name="fifa-2012-01-13">{{cite news | title = Players to watch in 2012 | url = https://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/clubfootball/news/newsid=1567609.html | publisher = FIFA | date = 13 January 2012 | accessdate =17 February 2012}}</ref>
In the [[2011–12 Premier League|2011–12 season]], Hoilett had the most dribbles per game among all Premier League players.<ref name="whoscored-2011-2012">{{cite news | title = Player Statistics Rankings of Premier League (2011/2012) | url = http://www.whoscored.com/Regions/252/Tournaments/2/Seasons/2935/Stages/5476/PlayerStatistics/England-Premier-League-2011-2012 | publisher = WhoScored.com | date = 10 May 2012 | accessdate = 2 January 2013}}</ref>
===Queens Park Rangers=== [[File:Chelsea 2 QPR 1 (15500879198).jpg|thumb|left|Hoilett (in white) playing against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in November 2014]] After refusing a contract renewal with Blackburn Rovers, Hoilett joined Queens Park Rangers on 27 July 2012 for a fee decided by tribunal. He signed a four-year contract.<ref>{{cite news|title=Junior joins R's revolution |url=http://www.qpr.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10373~2858641,00.html |publisher=QPR |date=27 July 2012 |accessdate=27 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120729200136/http://www.qpr.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10373~2858641%2C00.html |archivedate=29 July 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19015967|title= Junior Hoilett joins Queens Park Rangers from Blackburn Rovers | date= 27 July 2012}}</ref> He scored his first goal for QPR in a 3–2 [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] defeat to [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] on 26 September 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19645187 |title=QPR 2–3 Reading |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=26 September 2012 |accessdate=28 September 2012}}</ref> On 2 March 2013, Hoilett set-up teammate [[Loïc Rémy]] and played a crucial part in a 2–1 win over [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21556942|title=Southampton 1–2 QPR |publisher= [[BBC]] |date=2 March 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2014}}</ref> A combination of injuries and poor form meant that Hoilett had a frustrating first season at QPR, which resulted in relegation to the [[Football League Championship]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Reading v QPR|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/283166/report|accessdate=10 December 2014|date=28 April 2013}}</ref>
Hoilett scored his first goal of the [[2013–14 Football League Championship]] season in a 1–1 draw with [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23558561|title=Huddersfield 1–1 QPR |publisher= [[BBC]] |date=10 August 2013 |accessdate=23 February 2014}}</ref> Four months later, he scored his second goal of the season in a comfortable 3–0 win over [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]] at [[Loftus Road]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25098375|title=QPR 3–0 Bournemouth |publisher= [[BBC]] |date=3 December 2013 |accessdate=24 February 2014}}</ref> Hoilett grabbed an assist for the only goal of the game, when he crossed for [[Bobby Zamora]] to score in the 89th minute in QPR's 1–0 victory over [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] at [[Wembley Stadium]] in the [[2014 Football League Championship play-off Final]] to gain promotion back to the Premier League after an absence of one season.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/video-qpr-1-0-derby-highlights-zamora-goal-wins-championship-play-final-dramatic-fashion-1589812|title=VIDEO: QPR 1–0 Derby: Highlights; Zamora Goal Wins Championship Play-Off Final In Dramatic Fashion|publisher=[[International Business Times]]|date=24 May 2014|accessdate=27 May 2014}}</ref> After failing to agree a new contract with QPR at the end of the 2015–16 season, Hoilett left the club following the expiry of his contract.<ref name=Bluebirds>{{cite web|title=Cardiff City boss Neil Warnock signs Junior Hoilett as he immediately bolsters his Bluebirds team|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/cardiff-city-boss-neil-warnock-11989349|publisher=WalesOnline|accessdate=6 October 2016}}</ref>
===Cardiff City=== Following the appointment of [[Neil Warnock]] as manager, Hoilett signed with [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] on 6 October 2016, becoming Warnock's first signing at the club.<ref name=Bluebirds/> His debut came on 14 October, against severnside rivals, [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff City 2–1 Bristol City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37581994 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 October 2016 |accessdate=14 October 2016}}</ref> Hoilett scored his first goal for Cardiff during a 3–2 victory over [[Huddersfield Town F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] on 19 November 2016.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37958534 |title=Cardiff 3-2 Huddersfield |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=19 November 2016 |accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref> He went on to score one more goal before signing a one-year contract extension in May 2017.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40174267 |title=Cardiff City: Bluebirds contract extensions for Hoilett and Peltier |publisher=BBC Sport |date=6 June 2017 |accessdate=10 June 2017}}</ref>
The [[2017–18 Football League Championship|2017–18 season]] saw Hoilett's most productive season, finishing the season with 12 goals, including goals against former club, [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] and a brace against [[Mansfield Town F.C.|Mansfield Town]] in the [[FA Cup]], as Cardiff finished 2nd, gaining promotion to the [[Premier League]].<ref>{{soccerbase|52010|2017}}</ref> Hoilett was offered a new contract following the club promotion.<ref>{{cite news |title=Junior Hoilett: Cardiff City future unclear |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44486045 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 June 2018 |accessdate=15 June 2018}}</ref>
On 26 June 2018, Hoilett signed a three-year contract in the Welsh capital.<ref>{{cite news |title=Junior Hoilett: Winger signs new Cardiff City contract |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44614641 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 June 2018 |accessdate=26 June 2018}}</ref> He scored his first [[Premier League]] goal since 2012 in a 2–1 win over [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] on 30 November, which BBC Sport called a "fabulous first-time effort from 25 yards".<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff City 2–1 Wolves |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46312729 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 November 2018 |accessdate=2 December 2018}}</ref>
==International career== Hoilett was born in [[Brampton]], [[Ontario]]. As a child, he captained Canada's representative team at the 2001 [[Danone Nations Cup]] in [[Paris]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Danone Nations Cup Alumni |url=http://www.coupedanonecup.com/alumni.aspx |publisher=CoupeDanoneCup |accessdate=12 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314230927/http://www.coupedanonecup.com/alumni.aspx |archivedate=14 March 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>
Hoilett was eligible to play for [[Canada men's national soccer team|Canada]] or [[Jamaica national football team|Jamaica]] at international level.<ref name="fifa-2012-01-13"/> In February 2011, he rejected a call-up from the Canadian national team, stating that he wanted more time to develop his club career before committing to international football.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hoilett absent from Canadian soccer squad|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/soccer/story/2011/02/03/sp-canada-greece.html | first = John F. | last = Molinaro |publisher=CBC.ca|accessdate=6 February 2012 | date = 3 February 2011}}</ref> In January 2012, [[Jamaica Football Federation]] president [[Horace Burrell]] confirmed that he had approached the player's father about Hoilett representing Jamaica.<ref name="gleaner-2012-2-6">{{cite web|last=Wright|first=Nodley|title=New Boyz coming|url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20120129/sports/sports1.html|publisher=Jamaica Gleaner|accessdate=6 February 2012}}</ref> In March 2012, Hoilett told various media bodies that he would consider playing for [[England national football team|England]] if eligible.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hoilett – togetherness is key|url=http://www.skysports.com/video/inline/0,,16426_7585399,00.html|publisher=SkySports.com|accessdate=12 March 2012|date=10 March 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Premier League and Football League latest scores and results|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/17308534|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=12 March 2012|date=10 March 2012}}</ref>
Hoilett officially declared for Canada in September 2015, prior to the [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification – CONCACAF Fourth Round|fourth round of CONCACAF 2018 World Cup Qualifying]].<ref name="commits to Canada">{{cite web|title=Junior Hoilett commits to Canada Soccer|url=http://www.thespec.com/sports-story/5938311-junior-hoilett-commits-to-canada-soccer/|publisher=Hamilton Spectator|accessdate=30 September 2015}}</ref> He received his first international cap in a 1–1 draw against [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] on 13 October 2015 at [[Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium|RFK Stadium]] in [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref name="Canada MNT deliver impressive performance in Ghana draw">{{cite web|title=Canada MNT deliver impressive performance in Ghana draw|url=http://www.canadasoccer.com/-canada-mnt-deliver-impressive-performance-in-ghana-draw-p158721|publisher=Canada Soccer|accessdate=14 October 2015}}</ref> He officially got cap-tied to Canada after starting for Canada in a 2018 World Cup Qualification match against [[Honduras national football team|Honduras]]. Hoilett was named to Canada's squad for the [[2017 CONCACAF Gold Cup]] on June 27, 2017,<ref>{{cite web|first=Dave|last=Zeitlin|url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2017/06/27/canada-names-nine-mls-players-23-man-concacaf-gold-cup-roster|title=Canada names nine MLS players to 23-man CONCACAF Gold Cup roster|date=June 27, 2017}}</ref> and scored his first international goal in the quarterfinal, a 2–1 defeat to eventual finalists [[Jamaica national football team|Jamaica]] on July 20.<ref>{{cite web|first=Gavin|last=Day|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/soccer/gold-cup-canada-out-jamaica-strikes-early-1.4214890|title=Canada out of Gold Cup as Jamaica strikes quickly|date=July 20, 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== Hoilett's parents are of Jamaican descent;<ref name=lancs/> his father hails from [[Ocho Rios]] in Jamaica.<ref name="gleaner-2012-2-6"/> Hoilett's brother is Canada U-20 international Jaineil Hoilett.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.canadasoccer.com/players/profile.asp?playerid=1677&gender=male | title =Jaineil Hoilett Profile | publisher = Canadasoccer.com}}{{Dead link|date=July 2012}}</ref> who represented Canada at the [[2009 CONCACAF U-17 Championship]] and Canada's U-20 team against the United States in December 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=U.S. U-20 Men's National Team tops Canada 2–0 in friendly in Florida|url=http://www.nationalsoccerwire.com/news/458/12563|publisher=National Soccer Wire|accessdate=12 March 2012|date=18 December 2010}}</ref>

{{Use British English|date=September 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Matthew Connolly | image = Matthew.Connolly.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Connolly playing for [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] in 2016 | fullname = Matthew Thomas Martin Connolly<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.efl.com/siteassets/efl-documents/efl-professional-retain-list--free-transfers---2017-18.pdf |title=Club list of registered players: As at 19th May 2018: Cardiff City |publisher=English Football League |format=PDF |page=12 |accessdate=17 June 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1987|9|24|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Chipping Barnet|Barnet]], England | height = {{convert|1.88|m|order=flip}}<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.premierleague.com/en-gb/players/profile.overview.html/matthew-connolly|title= Premier League Player Profile Matthew Connolly |work=web page |publisher= Premier League |accessdate =18 June 2012}}</ref> | position = [[Defender (association football)|Defender]] | currentclub = [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] | clubnumber = 16 | youthyears1 = 1997–2006 | youthclubs1 = [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] | years1 = 2006–2008 | years2 = 2006–2007 | years3 = 2007–2008 | years4 = 2008–2012 | years5 = 2012 | years6 = 2012– | years7 = 2015 | clubs1 = [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] | clubs2 = → [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] (loan) | clubs3 = → [[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United]] (loan) | clubs4 = [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] | clubs5 = → [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] (loan) | clubs6 = [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] | clubs7 = → [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] (loan) | caps1 = 0 | caps2 = 5 | caps3 = 16 | caps4 = 116 | caps5 = 6 | caps6 = 137 | caps7 = 6 | goals1 = 0 | goals2 = 1 | goals3 = 2 | goals4 = 2 | goals5 = 0 | goals6 = 7 | goals7 = 1 | nationalyears1 = | nationalteam1 = | nationalcaps1 = | nationalgoals1 = | club-update = 21:42, 6 March 2018 (UTC) | ntupdate = }} '''Matthew Thomas Martin Connolly''' (born 24 September 1987) is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]].
Having started his career at [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] he went moved to [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]], going on to win the [[Football League Championship]] in 2011. It would be the first of three titles in four years, as he won the same division again on loan at [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] in 2012 and Cardiff in 2013, whom he had joined permanently one year previously.
==Career== Born in [[Chipping Barnet|Barnet]], London, Connolly attended Nicholas Breakspear R.C school started his career as a youth at Arsenal, eventually making the reserve side. In September 2006 he was made captain of Arsenal's reserves.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/-the-senior-players-impressed-me- | title=Banfield: 'The senior players impressed me' | publisher=Arsenal F.C. | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221073053/http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/-the-senior-players-impressed-me- | archivedate=21 February 2014 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> He made his first-team debut for Arsenal on 24 October 2006, starting a [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] third round match against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/6072672.stm |title=West Brom 0–2 Arsenal |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=24 October 2006 |accessdate=19 January 2016}}</ref>
On 23 November 2006 Arsenal announced he was going on loan to Bournemouth until 2 January 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/b/bournemouth/6177378.stm|title=Cherries sign Arsenal youngster|publisher=BBC Sport|work=BBC.co.uk |accessdate=28 October 2017}}</ref> In total he played seven games for Bournemouth (five in [[Football League One|League One]] and two in the [[FA Cup]]), and scored his first goal at senior level in a 2–0 win over [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]], on 5 December 2006.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/6201530.stm |title=Bournemouth 2–0 Nottm Forest |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=5 December 2006 |accessdate=8 March 2010}}</ref> He returned to Arsenal as scheduled at the start of January 2007,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bournemouth.vitalfootball.co.uk/matchprere.asp?a=45103 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071220020304/http://www.bournemouth.vitalfootball.co.uk/matchprere.asp?a=45103 |archivedate=20 December 2007 | title=Cherries v Bees | work=Vitalfootball | accessdate=4 January 2007 }}</ref> and came on as a substitute for [[Armand Traoré]] against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] in the League Cup Quarter-finals on 9 January.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/league_cup/6236687.stm |title=Liverpool 3–6 Arsenal |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=9 January 2007 |accessdate=19 January 2016}}</ref>
On 9 July 2007 Arsenal announced he would be spending the whole of the [[2007-08 in English football|2007–08]] season on loan to [[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/matthew-connolly-joins-colchester-on-loan | title=Matthew Connolly joins Colchester United on loan | publisher=Arsenal F.C. | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305135454/http://www.arsenal.com/news/news-archive/matthew-connolly-joins-colchester-on-loan | archivedate=5 March 2016 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> although he eventually was recalled midway through the loan on 2 January 2008.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/colchester_united/7165220.stm | publisher=BBC Sport | title=Colchester to lose on-loan Gunner | date=30 December 2007 | accessdate=12 May 2010}}</ref>
===Queens Park Rangers=== The same day, his transfer to [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] was announced, after a lack of first-team opportunities were offered by Arsenal.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11711/3015996/connolly-links-up-with-qpr | work=Sky Sports | title=Sky Sports – Football – Premier League – News – Connolly links up with QPR}}</ref> His debut came on 5 January, in a 1–0 loss to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in the [[FA Cup]]. He scored his first goal for QPR against Blackpool on 16 January 2010.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8452528.stm |title=Blackpool 2 – 2 QPR |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=16 January 2010 |accessdate=8 March 2010}}</ref> In the meantime, in November, he received his first call-up to the [[England national under-21 football team|England U-21 squad]], where he joined Arsenal teammate [[Theo Walcott]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arsenal.com/news/reserves-news/matt-connolly-called-up-for-under-21-action|title=Matt Connolly called up for Under-21 action|website=Arsenal.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221070434/http://www.arsenal.com/news/reserves-news/matt-connolly-called-up-for-under-21-action|archivedate=21 February 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> His second goal came on 6 March against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] in a 3–1 win.
During the 2010–11 season, Connolly played a part in QPR's Championship title win playing 36 out of 43 games.
He joined Reading on a loan on 31 January 2012 until the end of the 2011–12 season.<ref>{{cite web|title=Reading sign QPR defender Matthew Connolly on loan|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/16812181.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=31 January 2012|date=31 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Royals swoop for Matthew Connolly |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~2594815,00.html |publisher=Reading Football Club |accessdate=31 January 2012 |date=10 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120418043507/http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10306~2594815%2C00.html |archivedate=18 April 2012 |df= }}</ref> He made his debut on 11 February 2012 in a 2–0 win against [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]]. He only played 6 times during Reading's promotion push which resulted in Reading winning the Championship title.
===Cardiff City=== [[File:Matthew Connolly.jpg|thumb|upright|Connolly playing for [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] in 2012]]
On 20 August 2012, QPR had accepted a £500,000 bid from [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] for Connolly's services.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff City close to signing QPR defender Matthew Connolly |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/cardiff-city-close-signing-qpr-2026055 |work=South Wales Echo |date=20 August 2012 |accessdate=3 February 2014}}</ref> On 22 August, the deal was completed and Connolly signed a contract that would keep him at the [[Cardiff City Stadium]] for 3 years.<ref>{{cite news|title=DEAL DONE: CONNOLLY SIGNS FOR CITY |url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10335~2896709,00.html |work=Cardiff City FC |date=22 August 2012 |accessdate=10 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120824211423/http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10335~2896709%2C00.html |archivedate=24 August 2012 |df= }}</ref> He made his debut in the [[Severnside derby]] against [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] on 25 August. He scored his first and second goal for the club in a 3–0 win over [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] on 29 September. His third goal came a month later against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]], and later scored his fourth against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]]. Making thirty-six appearances and scoring five goals, Connolly was a key figure as Cardiff won the [[2012-13 Football League Championship|Championship]] title, the third time in successive seasons that Connolly has achieved the feat.
[[File:Matthew Connolly 2015.jpg|thumb|left|Connolly playing for Cardiff City in 2015.]] He started the [[Premier League]] season playing at right back until new signing [[Kevin Theophile-Catherine]] became a permanent fixture in the side. Cardiff were relegated after just one season in the top flight. Connolly had then returned to the starting eleven partnering [[Mark Hudson (footballer, born 1982)|Mark Hudson]] in a 1–1 draw at [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Blackburn Rovers 1–1 Cardiff City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28646428 |work=BBC Sport |date=8 August 2014 |accessdate=8 August 2014}}</ref>
On 19 March 2015 Connolly joined another Championship side, [[Watford F.C.|Watford]], on loan until the end of the [[2014–15 in English football|2014–15 season]], despite having played 26 times for Cardiff that season. Manager [[Russell Slade]] stated the deal was a business rather than a footballing decision, with Connolly expressing his surprise at the move.<ref>{{cite news |title=Matt Connolly says the Watford squad is more talented than the QPR, Reading and Cardiff City sides he was promoted to the Premier League with |url=http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/sport/12869600.Connolly__Talent_in_Watford_squad_is_better_than_teams_I_ve_been_promoted_with/ |work=Watford Observer |date=6 April 2015 |accessdate=7 April 2015}}</ref> Whilst at Watford, Connolly achieved the feat of being promoted to the [[Premier League]] for the fourth time with four different clubs (QPR, Reading, Cardiff and Watford). At Watford Connolly scored once; in a 3–1 win at Nottingham Forest.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/32213813 |title=Nottm Forest 1–3 Watford |publisher=[[BBC Sport]] |date=15 April 2015 |accessdate=19 January 2016}}</ref>
Connolly rejoined the Cardiff squad for the [[2015–16 Cardiff City F.C. season|2015–16 season]], earning himself a permanent place in the side alongside [[Sean Morrison (footballer)|Sean Morrison]]. He had become of interest to other clubs during the January transfer window, due to his impressive performances that season. These feats thus earned him a contract extension till 2019 and also the club's Player of the Year award.<ref>{{cite news |title=Connolly signs long-term deal |url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/news/article/connolly-signs-long-term-city-deal-2908639.aspx |work=Cardiff City F.C. |publisher=Official Site |date=19 January 2016 |accessdate=19 January 2016}}</ref><ref name=Player >{{cite news |title=Cardiff City end of season awards RECAP: Matt Connolly named Player of the Year |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/cardiff-city-end-season-awards-11299527 |work=Wales Online |date=7 May 2016 |accessdate=7 May 2016}}</ref>

{{good article}} {{Use British English|date=June 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Stuart O'Keefe | image = Stuart OKeefe.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = O'Keefe playing for [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] in 2015 | fullname = Stuart Antony Alan O'Keefe<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/staticFiles/4e/bd/0,,10794~179534,00.pdf |format=PDF |page=4 |title=Professional retain lists & free transfers 2012/13 |publisher=The Football League |date=May 2013 |accessdate=15 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140802074454/http://www.football-league.co.uk/staticFiles/4e/bd/0,,10794~179534,00.pdf |archivedate=2 August 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1991|3|4|df=y}}<ref name="Hugman2009-10"/> | birth_place = [[Eye, Suffolk|Eye]], England | height = {{height|m=1.73|precision=0}}<ref name="Hugman2009-10">{{Cite book | editor-first = Barry J. | editor-last = Hugman | title = The PFA Footballers' Who's Who 2009–10 | year = 2009 | publisher = Mainstream Publishing | isbn = 978-1-84596-474-0}}</ref> | position = [[Midfielder]] | currentclub = [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] | clubnumber = | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = Scole Lads | youthyears2 = 2001–2007 | youthclubs2 = [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] | youthyears3 = 2007–2008 | youthclubs3 = [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]] | years1 = 2008–2010 | clubs1 = [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]] | caps1 = 10 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2010–2015 | clubs2 = [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] | caps2 = 36 | goals2 = 1 | years3 = 2014 | clubs3 = → [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] (loan) | caps3 = 4 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2015– | clubs4 = [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] | caps4 = 38 | goals4 = 2 | years5 = 2017 | clubs5 = → [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]] (loan) | caps5 = 18 | goals5 = 4 | years6 = 2017–2018 | clubs6 = → [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] (loan) | caps6 = 21 | goals6 = 0 | years7 = 2018–2019 | clubs7 = → [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]] (loan) | caps7 = 11 | goals7 = 0 | club-update = 08:46, 5 January 2019 (UTC) }} '''Stuart Antony Alan O'Keefe''' (born 4 March 1991) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]].
He began his career with [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]], spending six years in the club's youth academy system, but was released as a teenager without making an appearance for the first team. Following his release, O'Keefe joined the academy at [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]], making his first-team debut for the club in 2008, during a [[EFL League One|League One]] match, at the age of 17. In 2010, he completed a move to Championship club [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] on a free transfer and went on to make over 50 appearances in all competitions for the club during a five-year spell, helping the club gain promotion to the Premier League via the [[2013 Football League Championship play-off Final|2013 Championship play-off Final]], also spending a brief period on loan at [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] in late 2014. In January 2015, he moved to Cardiff City for an undisclosed fee.
==Early life== O'Keefe was born in [[Eye, Suffolk|Eye]], Suffolk.<ref>{{Hugman|24820|accessdate=28 August 2017}}</ref> He grew up in the village of [[Gislingham]], Suffolk and attended Gislingham Primary School and later [[Hartismere School]].<ref name="footballlife">{{cite web |url=http://www.dissexpress.co.uk/sport/football/feature-football-life-lives-up-to-the-dream-1-434992 |title=Feature: Football life lives up to the dream |newspaper=Diss Express |date=2 February 2009 |accessdate=29 October 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161030000141/http://www.dissexpress.co.uk/sport/football/feature-football-life-lives-up-to-the-dream-1-434992 |archive-date=30 October 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="Ex-Town teen to face Chelsea in FA Cup">{{cite news |title = Ex-Town teen to face Chelsea in FA Cup |url = http://www.greenun24.co.uk/ipswich-town/latest-news/ex_town_teen_to_face_chelsea_in_fa_cup_1_168699?ot=archant.PrintFriendlyPageLayout.ot |date = 10 December 2007 |accessdate = 24 August 2012 |archive-url = https://archive.is/20130420045832/http://www.greenun24.co.uk/ipswich-town/latest-news/ex_town_teen_to_face_chelsea_in_fa_cup_1_168699?ot=archant.PrintFriendlyPageLayout.ot |archive-date = 20 April 2013 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref> He is a supporter of [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref name="footballlife"/>
==Career== ===Youth=== Having attracted the attention of scouts from several clubs whilst playing for local youth team Scole Lads, O'Keefe was invited to train with [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]]'s under-nine team. However, he later signed a youth deal with their [[East Anglian derby|East Anglian]] rivals [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]], joining the club at the age of nine and playing alongside [[Jordan Rhodes]] and [[Ed Upson]] in the academy during his time at the club.<ref name="footballlife"/> However, he failed to make an appearance for the first team and was released at the end of the [[2006–07 in English football|2006–07 season]] after Ipswich decided against offering him a scholarship,<ref name="Ex-Town teen to face Chelsea in FA Cup"/> believing that he would be unable to compete physically at under-18 level.<ref name="footballlife"/> O'Keefe later commented on his release "It was disappointing to be released by Ipswich, especially since I had been there from such a young age, but I always kept believing in myself".<ref name="Ex-Town teen to face Chelsea in FA Cup"/>
Following his release, O'Keefe spent one month on trial at [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] and impressed the club's coaching staff, including youth coach [[Gordon Cowans]],<ref name="footballlife"/> but was forced to leave the club, who were only willing to offer him a one-year youth contract,<ref name="Showdown">{{cite news |url=http://www.echo-news.co.uk/sport/4724131.O_Keefe_set_for_Gills_showdown/ |title=O'Keefe set for Gills showdown |newspaper=Southend Echo |first=Chris |last=Phillips |date=6 November 2009 |accessdate=27 October 2016}}</ref> after struggling to travel to the Midlands-based club on a regular basis as he continued to prepare for his GCSEs. He was also offered a trial with [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]],<ref name="Prideofanglia">{{cite web |url=http://prideofanglia.com/page.php?page=playerProfile&fullname=Stuart%20OKeefe |title=Stuart O'Keefe |publisher=Pride of Anglia |accessdate=21 October 2016}}</ref> scoring during a friendly match for the club but O'Keefe again moved on after Forest stalled over offering him a contract as they were only willing to offer him a one-year youth deal.<ref name="Ex-Town teen to face Chelsea in FA Cup"/><ref name="Showdown"/>
===Southend United=== O'Keefe attended a trial with [[Southend United F.C.|Southend United]] in November 2007 at the age of 16, having been recommended to the club by a scout working for [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], and was offered a two-year scholarship just days after arriving at the club.<ref name="footballlife"/> In his first season with the academy, O'Keefe was part of the Southend team that reached the quarter-final of the [[FA Youth Cup]] and also featured for the reserves on several occasions.<ref name="Ex-Town teen to face Chelsea in FA Cup"/> O'Keefe made his first-team debut for Southend on 18 November 2008, at home to [[A.F.C. Telford United]] in a 2–0 win in the [[FA Cup]] first-round replay as a late substitute in place of [[Alan McCormack]],<ref name="Southend 2-0 AFC Telford">{{cite news | title = Southend 2–0 AFC Telford | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/fa_cup/7726993.stm | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 18 November 2008 | accessdate = 8 February 2009}}</ref> having signed his first professional contract with the club the week before.<ref name="procontract">{{cite news |url=http://www.echo-news.co.uk/sport/3841081.O_Keefe_signs_professional_deal_with_Shrimpers/ |title=O'Keefe signs professional deal with Shrimpers |newspaper=Southend Echo |first=Chris |last=Phillips |date=12 November 2008 |accessdate=21 October 2016}}</ref> He made his debut in [[EFL League One|League One]] two months later against [[Leyton Orient F.C.|Leyton Orient]] on 20 January 2009 in a 1–1 away draw, again coming on as a substitute in the 84th minute for [[Alex Revell]] and nearly scoring late in the match with a volley.<ref name="Leyton Orient 1-1 Southend">{{cite news | title = Leyton Orient 1–1 Southend | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_2/7824202.stm | publisher = BBC Sport | date = 20 January 2009 | accessdate = 8 February 2009}}</ref><ref name="Hungry">{{cite news |url=http://www.echo-news.co.uk/sport/4069554.O_Keefe_hungry_for_more_first_team_chances/ |title=O'Keefe hungry for more first team chances |newspaper=Southend Echo |first=Chris |last=Phillips |date=23 January 2009 |accessdate=27 October 2016}}</ref>
The following week, after one further substitute appearance, O'Keefe was handed his first league start for Southend by manager [[Steve Tilson]] against [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] at [[Elland Road]] on 27 January 2009. However, this proved to be his last appearance for the club during the 2008–09 season.<ref name="sb0809"/> Despite this, O'Keefe was nominated for the League One Apprentice of the Year award,<ref name="apprentice">{{cite news |url=http://www.echo-news.co.uk/sport/4099290.O_Keefe_shortlisted_for_awards/ |title=O'Keefe shortlisted for awards |newspaper=Southend Echo |first=Chris |last=Phillips |date=4 February 2009 |accessdate=28 October 2016}}</ref> eventually losing out to [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]] defender [[Tom Aldred]].<ref name="Aldred">{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_conf/8401599.stm |title=Carlisle defender Tom Aldred tipped by Workington boss |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 December 2009 |accessdate=28 October 2016}}</ref> The following season, O'Keefe featured more regularly for the first team, making nine appearances in total despite missing two months of the season due to a hernia injury sustained in a match against [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] on 26 January 2010.<ref name="Southendreturn">{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/southend_utd/8573138.stm |title= Stuart O'Keefe set for Southend return after injury |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 March 2010 |accessdate=21 October 2016}}</ref> Following his departure from [[Roots Hall]], the club's head of youth director Ricky Duncan praised O'Keefe's attitude, stating "Stuart was always very driven and single-minded and he was different to a lot of the other lads in that regard."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.echo-news.co.uk/sport/blues/10449589.Southend_United_s_Ricky_Duncan__I_m_proud_of_what_Stuart_O_Keefe_has_achieved_with_Crystal_Palace/ |title=Southend United's Ricky Duncan: I'm proud of what Stuart O'Keefe has achieved with Crystal Palace |newspaper=Southend Echo |first=Chris |last=Phillips |date=29 May 2013 |accessdate=21 October 2016}}</ref>
===Crystal Palace=== On 18 August 2010, O'Keefe signed for [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] on an initial one-year contract after impressing manager [[George Burley]] in a trial match against [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] reserves, having been recommended to Burley by his assistant manager [[Dougie Freedman]] who had played alongside O'Keefe at Southend.<ref name="Disseagles">{{cite web |url=http://www.dissexpress.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/o-keefe-signs-for-eagles-1-813819 |title=O'Keefe signs for Eagles |newspaper=Diss Express |date=20 August 2010 |accessdate=1 November 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161103233834/http://www.dissexpress.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/o-keefe-signs-for-eagles-1-813819 |archive-date=3 November 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> On his signing, Burley described O'Keefe as "a young player with big potential".<ref name="Palacesigning">{{cite web |url=http://www.croydonadvertiser.co.uk/burley-adds-squad-signing-winger-o-keefe/story-11361141-detail/story.html |title=Burley adds to his squad with signing of winger O'Keefe |publisher=Croydon Advertiser |date=18 August 2010 |accessdate=28 October 2016}}</ref> The transfer was free, although Southend would receive a percentage of any transfer fee for O'Keefe in his first 36 months at [[Selhurst Park]].<ref name="Joinspalace">{{cite news |url=http://www.echo-news.co.uk/sport/8342260.O_Keefe_joins_Palace/ |title=Stuart O'Keefe joins Crystal Palace |newspaper=Southend Echo |first=Chris |last=Phillips |date=19 August 2010 |accessdate=21 October 2016}}</ref> He made his debut for the club on 20 November 2010 as a substitute in place of [[Paddy McCarthy]] during a 3–2 defeat to [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]], later being substituted himself in the 89th minute of the match for [[Pablo Couñago]] as Palace pushed for an equaliser.<ref name="Palacedebut">{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/9194912.stm |title=Sheffield United 3–2 Crystal Palace |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 November 2010 |accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref> In his first season at Selhurst Park, O'Keefe was a back up player in the squad and made just four appearances during the course of the season.<ref name="sb1011"/> In the 2011–12 season, O'Keefe was given a chance to impress early on in the season in the League Cup, playing five times in the competition during the season as the team reached the semi-final, including starting in the team's 2–1 quarter final victory over Manchester United on 30 November 2011 at [[Old Trafford]].<ref name="Manutd">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/15850177 |title=Manchester United 1–2 Crystal Palace (aet) |publisher=BBC Sport |date=30 November 2011 |accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref> Later in the season, O'Keefe was part of the end of season run in due to injuries and finished the season with 19 appearances for the first team, which saw him offered a new three-year contract with Palace that would last until summer 2015.<ref name="Palacecontract">{{cite news |url=http://www.croydonadvertiser.co.uk/stuart-finished-article-potential/story-16183302-detail/story.html |title=Stuart not the finished article |newspaper=Croydon Advertiser |date=25 May 2012 |accessdate=29 October 2016 }}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref>
During the 2012–13 season, Palace achieved promotion to the [[Premier League]] via the Championship play-offs after finishing fifth.O'Keefe featured just five times in the league during the season although he did make two appearances during the play-offs, replacing [[Wilfried Zaha]] as a late substitute during the second leg of their semi-final victory over [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]], and then playing the majority of the [[2013 Football League Championship play-off Final|2013 Championship play-off Final]] after replacing [[Kagisho Dikgacoi]] due to injury after just 17 minutes as Palace claimed a 1–0 victory in extra-time to earn promotion.<ref name="Folklore">{{cite web |url=http://www.dissexpress.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/stuart-o-keefe-aiming-to-etch-his-name-into-crystal-palace-folklore-1-5122970 |title=Stuart O'Keefe aiming to etch his name into Crystal Palace folklore |newspaper=Diss Express |date=23 May 2013 |accessdate=1 November 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161103215035/http://www.dissexpress.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/stuart-o-keefe-aiming-to-etch-his-name-into-crystal-palace-folklore-1-5122970 |archive-date=3 November 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="play-offfinal">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/22592831 |title=Crystal Palace 1–0 Watford |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 May 2013 |accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref> At the start of the club's Premier League campaign the following season, on 31 August 2013, O'Keefe sealed a 3–1 victory in Palace's first three points of their Premier League return in the 92nd minute at home to [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] with a curling 20 yard shot after coming on as a late substitute,<ref name="Firstgoal">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23822589 |title=Crystal Palace 3-1 Sunderland |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 August 2013 |accessdate=31 August 2013}}</ref> the first senior goal of his career and what later turned out to be his only goal for Palace.<ref name="sb1314"/>
At the start of the 2014–15 season, O'Keefe featured in Palace's opening two matches of the Premier League season, defeats to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] and [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], but suffered an ankle injury in the latter which kept him out of the team for two months that saw him omitted from the club's 25-man squad for the Premier League season by new Palace manager [[Neil Warnock]].<ref name="whois">{{cite news |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/just-who-cardiff-citys-new-8527504 |title=Who is Stuart O'Keefe? Cardiff City are set to sign him but here's everything else you need to know about the Crystal Palace man |work=WalesOnline |publisher=Media Wales |first=Terry |last=Phillips |date=27 January 2015 |accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref> Lacking match fitness on his return, Warnock made O'Keefe available for a [[Loan (sports)|loan]] move in order to gain playing time and, following a potential loan move to [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] collapsing after they decided to sign [[Francis Coquelin]] on loan from Arsenal instead,<ref name="Coquelin">{{cite web |url=http://www.croydonadvertiser.co.uk/crystal-palace-midfielder-wanted-charlton-loan/story-24561126-detail/story.html |title=Crystal Palace midfielder was wanted by Charlton on loan |publisher=Croydon Advertiser |first=Mark |last=Ritson |date=19 November 2014 |accessdate=29 October 2016 }}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref> Warnock stated that he could not "understand how nobody has come in for him".<ref name="Baffled">{{cite web |url=http://www.croydonadvertiser.co.uk/palace-boss-baffled-lack-stuart-o-keefe-loan/story-24572526-detail/story.html |title=Palace boss baffled by lack of Stuart O'Keefe loan interest |publisher=Croydon Advertsier |first=Mark |last=Ritson |date=21 November 2014 |accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref>
On 27 November 2014, O'Keefe eventually secured a loan move away from Palace on the final day of the emergency loan window,<ref name="Interview">{{cite web |url=http://www.sportsmole.co.uk/football/cardiff-city/interview/interview-stuart-okeefe_203329.html |title=Interview: Stuart O'Keefe |publisher=Sports Mole |first=Matt |last=Law |date=3 February 2015 |accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref> joining struggling Championship club [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] on loan until 1 January 2015,<ref>{{cite web|title =O'Keefe Goes Out On Loan|url = https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2014/november/okeefe-joins-blackpool/|publisher=Crystal Palace F.C.|date =27 November 2014| accessdate =27 November 2014}}</ref> along with [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] defender [[Kevin Foley (footballer)|Kevin Foley]].<ref name="BBCblackpoolloan">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/30228277 |title=Blackpool: Kevin Foley and Stuart O'Keefe join on loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 November 2016 |accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref> He made his debut on 29 November 2014, starting in a 1–1 draw with [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]], being replaced by [[Nathan Delfouneso]] after 56 minutes,<ref name="Blackpooldebut">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/30155877 |title=Rotherham United 1–1 Blackpool |publisher=BBC Sport |date=29 November 2014 |accessdate=21 October 2016}}</ref> and went on to make four appearances for the team before returning to Palace.<ref name="sb1415"/> On his return to Selhurst Park, O'Keefe found himself under a new manager for the fourth time since August 2014, following the appointment of [[Alan Pardew]]. Despite being handed a starting spot in Pardew's first match in charge at the club, a 4–0 win over non-League team [[Dover Athletic F.C.|Dover Athletic]] in the third round of the FA Cup on 4 January 2015,<ref name="Dover">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/30614379#tab-0 |title=Dover Athletic 0–4 Crystal Palace |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 January 2015 |accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref> he was later informed that he was not part of the manager's new plans at the club.<ref name="whois"/>
===Cardiff City=== On 28 January 2015, O'Keefe signed for Championship club [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]], who beat off competition from [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]],<ref name="Interview"/> for an undisclosed fee on a two-and-a-half-year contract,<ref>{{cite web|title=O'Keefe Joins Cardiff City |publisher=Crystal Palace F.C. |url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2015/january/okeefe-joins-cardiff-city/|date=28 January 2015|accessdate=28 January 2015}}</ref> joining former Palace teammates [[Danny Gabbidon]] and Kagisho Dikgacoi at the [[Cardiff City Stadium]].<ref name="Gabbidon">{{cite web |url=http://www.croydonadvertiser.co.uk/crystal-palace-midfielder-joins-cardiff-city/story-25936240-detail/story.html |title=Crystal Palace midfielder joins Cardiff City |publisher=Croydon Advertiser |date=28 January 2015 |accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref> He made his debut against [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]], having trained with the team for just two days following the completion of his transfer,<ref name="Interview"/> in a 2–0 loss.<ref name="sb1415"/> He featured in the following two matches but,<ref name="sb1415"/> with heavy competition from [[Peter Whittingham]], [[Joe Ralls]] and [[Aron Gunnarsson]], he did not appear for the first team again until 11 April and made a total of just six appearances during the second half of the season for Cardiff.<ref name="Outcast">{{cite news |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/cardiff-city-outcast-midfield-regular-10859135 |title=From Cardiff City outcast to midfield regular... Stuart O'Keefe is not in the mood to relinquish Bluebirds shirt after big battle for starting spot |work=WalesOnline |publisher=Media Wales |first=Steve |last=Tucker |date=8 February 2016 |accessdate=28 August 2017}}</ref>
The start of the following season continued the same trend for O'Keefe as he made just eight appearances during the first five months of the season before returning to the starting line up against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] on 16 January 2016, in a match that Cardiff went on to win 3–1.<ref name="Outcast"/> O'Keefe's performances saw him establish himself in the first team and his attitude to being left out of the team for long periods drew praise from Cardiff manager [[Russell Slade]] who commented "Stuart has got a fantastic attitude, he's a real, real good professional, even when he wasn't in the side he was pushing. [...] some players when they're not in the side get disillusioned and want to move on, but not O'Keefe."<ref name="Zerotohero">{{cite news |url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/zero-cardiff-city-hero-story-11130606 |title=From zero to Cardiff City hero... The story of Stuart O'Keefe's remarkable rise |work=WalesOnline |publisher=Media Wales |first=Phil |last=Smith |date=4 April 2016 |accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref> He later scored his first goal for the club in a 2–0 victory during a [[Severnside derby]] match against [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] on 5 March 2016,<ref name="Bristolgoal">{{cite news |title=Bristol City 0–2 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35659859 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 March 2016 |accessdate=5 March 2016}}</ref> adding his second one-month later with the winning goal during a 2–1 win over [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] on 2 April.<ref name="Derbygoal">{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35902254 |title=Cardiff City 2–1 Derby County |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2 April 2016 |accessdate=29 October 2016}}</ref> He finished the season having made 27 appearances for the club in all competitions, the most appearances he has made during a season to date and the first time in his career he made over 20 appearances in a single season.<ref name="sb1516"/>
His impressive form during the second half of the 2015–16 season saw him handed a new contract during the summer, keeping him at Cardiff until summer 2019.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff City: Stuart O'Keefe signs new Bluebirds deal |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36958614 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 August 2016 |accessdate=3 August 2016}}</ref> After featuring as an unused substitute during the first match of the 2016–17 season, O'Keefe was handed his first appearance of the season in a 1–0 defeat to [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]] in the first round of the [[EFL Cup]], where he suffered a broken arm in extra-time.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff City's Stuart O'Keefe suffers suspected broken arm |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37059497 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=12 August 2016 |accessdate=12 August 2016}}</ref> He made his return to the team one month later on 25 September, helping Cardiff to their second win of the season during a 2–1 win against [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Rotherham United 1–2 Cardiff City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37392288 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 September 2016 |accessdate=24 September 2016}}</ref> However, with first-team opportunities limited at Cardiff, on 31 January 2017, O'Keefe joined League One club [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]] on loan until 1 May 2017,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mkdons.com/news/article/2016-17/dons-bring-in-bluebirds-midfielder-3549072.aspx |title=Dons bring in Bluebirds midfielder |publisher=Milton Keynes Dons F.C. |date=31 January 2017 |accessdate=1 February 2017 }}</ref> making his debut for the club as a substitute in place of [[Chuks Aneke]] during a 1–1 draw with [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] on 4 February 2017.<ref name="Donsdebut">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38778821 |title=MK Dons 1–1 Bolton |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 February 2017 |accessdate=4 February 2017}}</ref> He made a total of 18 appearances during the loan spell, scoring four times.<ref name="sb1617">{{Soccerbase season|49628|2016|access-date=28 August 2017}}</ref>
On 31 August 2017, O'Keefe joined League One club [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]] on loan until the end of the [[2017–18 Portsmouth F.C. season|2017–18 season]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.portsmouthfc.co.uk/news/2017/august/okeefe-signs-on-loan/ |title=O'Keefe signs on loan |publisher=Portsmouth F.C. |date=31 August 2017 |accessdate=31 August 2017}}</ref> At the start of the following season, O'Keefe was sent out on loan for the second successive season, joining [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pafc.co.uk/news/2018/august/its-ok/ |title=It's O'K |publisher=Plymouth Argyle F.C. |date=24 August 2018 |accessdate=24 August 2018}}</ref>. He returned to Cardiff in January 2019.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.plymouthherald.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/loan-midfielder-stuart-okeefe-not-2347837|title=On-loan midfielder Stuart O'Keefe will not be returning to Plymouth Argyle|publisher=plymouthherald.co.uk|date=20 December 2018|accessdate=18 January 2019}}</ref>
==Style of play== After originally beginning his career as a winger,<ref name="Palacesigning"/> O'Keefe switched to central midfield and was described by former Cardiff City manager [[Russell Slade]] as a "hard working, energetic, athletic midfield player."<ref name="whois"/> Slade also praised O'Keefe for his determination when not playing regularly in the first team, stating " Stuart will roll his sleeves up, work harder, to try and show his manager and the coaching staff that he's capable of playing in the first team."<ref name="Zerotohero"/>
==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 1 January 2019}}
